number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												This is honestly one of the most bizarre games i've played in a long time but despite all the madness it does make for a fun experience. In it you play a spy called Polyblank in what is a spoof of 50's and 60's era spy films. The game is so bizarre it's hard to describe it. It really is one of those things you need to experience for yourself. The basic formula of the game is each level is an open area you can expore through at will and discover the various strange and funny events and mini-games in each level. There are some fun mini-games in this game (Wedding Quake being my favourite) that are parodies of classic games. This is a short game but it is packed with a lot of fun.The Good- This game was a lot of fun to play. Each level has a lot of random stuff to discover.- I enjoyed this games humour. It's a bit off the wall and bizarre which was right up my street.- The visual style of this game really stands out and looks great a bit like a weird Hanna-Barbara cartoon.The Bad- It is pretty short. Even with taking my time and almost fully exploring all the levels my playtime came to just over 3 hours. - This games humour might not appeal to everyone.Overall this was a fun but regrettably short game which i enjoyed a lot more than i expected. 7.5/10

content:
Posted: April 9
												I finished this game over a year ago.  Naturally, I had to come back on a day when they least expected to write a review.It had to be today.  Otherwise, they'd find me.This game was FUN, from beginning to end.  Yes, it has randomness and surrealism and...kissy robots.  But that's only part of it--and all of it.  It is an adventure game, so you are actually working towards a goal.  You have to play it to understand the rest of it--or none of it.  Or something.But seriously, play this game.  I'm not usually a compulsive smiler, but this had me grinning at frequently regular intervals.  I would have been quite ashamed if I hadn't been enjoying myself so much.  In fact, it's been too long.  I think I'm gonna go play it again.Crud.  Now they'll find me.  It's exactly what they'd expect.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
												I should have read the game description rather than looking at the pretty pictures. This game is well... eh? Like many other people who played this game, I went into it thinking there was something else.The initial cut scene and first level set you up for what appears to be a journey like no other. The design and aesthetic of the game capture you with an initial impression that is quirky yet filled with mystery which you assume will unfold into a carefully articulated plot. Sure, there were clues like the whoopie cushion that were used to soften the situation like the room does to frozen water ice. However, I wish it hadnt gone too far. As you progress further into the game, you begin to realize that a story isnt really there. Instead, JazzPunk turns into a walking art gallery. You spend the large portion of your time listening to the ambient noise, interacting with the environment. This isnt a bad thing either because they throw in alot of hidden references that make the experience entertaining and memorable.Ultimately, JazzPunk is a series of events that were created where the developers can input there own type of humor. The length of gameplay is perfect for this type of thing. Like a buffet, the playthrough gives the gamer enough time to indulge in everything and then bail before your eyes adjust to the swine surrounding you. If it was any longer, the whole experience would have been dissapointing. TLDR: Overall, JazzPunk is good. If you dont like looking at stall art for 3 hours, this game isnt for you.

As far as I can tell, there are no fail states (a conclusion I only reached after spending WAY too much time trying to avoid being seen by a security camera that simply blinked at me and carried no consequences). This lack of tension lowers the challenge, obviously, but it allows you to freely explore every nook and cranny of this bizarre world looking for the jokes and non sequiturs. And let's face it, that's why you're here. Just take your Missionoyl and enjoy the ride.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												Is Jazzpunk good? Yes.Is Jazzpunk short? HELL YES.I took my time, tried various things and I finished the game in barely 2 hours. To a rather unsatisfying ending.Don't get me wrong; Jazzpunk is a good game. If you know about computers, video games, the 80s and 90s pop culture and current geek pop culture, there's plenty of laughs to be had. Maybe times I caught myself going "AW YEAH" while chuckling. Even a few "I can't believe they did that.".But, in the end, the game is incredibly underwhelming.Under the guise of a 70s-era spy show set in a computer, you find yourself trying to get a russian data tape, then find an old enemy, save yourself and save someone else. And that's it.Lots of slapstick comedy, but... is it worth 15$? No.10$ would have been a steep yet fair price, in my opinion. For two hours of gameplay, if would be on par with a movie admission ticket.But I complain about movies charging more than 10$ for a 1.5 hours running time feature-length movie, I would be remiss in pointing out the same flaws with a video game.If you want to support an indie developper with a great sense of humour, and maybe Jim Sterling at the same time, then go right ahead.However, if you are looking for anything that will "go the distance", so to speak, then don't. And that's with the gimmick of "click on everything at least once" of exploration games, such as this one.TL;DR:Hilarious if you're a 25-or-plus years old geek, finished awfully and disappointingly fast.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												A must-play for fans of Top Secret!, Airplane, Naked Gun, Ren and Stimpy, etc. The game, which is sadly only about 2 hours long, is absolutely loaded with jokes, puns, and references to other video games and television. A child of the 90s will feel right at home with all of the references, but anyone with a sense of humor can appreciate the entire game. Not only is the game very funny, but it's also very psychadelic. I feel like certain parts of this game are more drug-induced than the LSD Simulator that was released years ago on the PS1... Very interesting.tl;dr: Buy the game immidiately and play it while drinking with friends. You will die laughing.

number of helpful: 10 of 18 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												Essentially a three-hour-long sightseeing tour!The lack of graphic settings beyond resolution and Unity presets is a significant downside, especially since the FOV appears to be locked at a nauseously low view angle.'s gonna make your head spin, especially in the early bits.Overall, the complete lack of options gives way to sensory overload.Especially in the first level, with its bright, clashing colours; but all the way through, music or disorienting sounds playing from multiple sources at once make this basically-a-theme-park-not-a-game a chore at times.Jazzpunk is essentially a series of things to click on numerous times to see what they have to say!There's no failure state to it, but it does have its neat moments, including some neat minigames, some of which based off its own interpretations of what a reference is.(Among them a first-person take on the Street Fighter car smashing bonus thingery as well as "Wedding Qake", which you'd have to experience for yourself for my lack of writing experience couldn't bring the impression it left on me across properly.)However, it lacks length (The game is 3 hours long, and that's counting all side exploration, conversations and achievement hunting)and tends to cause nausea, motion- and simulation-sickness, as a number of people point out on its Steam Forums. Hasn't been fixed. No FOV slider or option to turn down or off the volume of mind-drilling ambient saxophone droning noises.The humour may or may not appeal to you, but I definitely cannot recommend this game to you at full price.

Posted: February 19, 2014
												What can I say about Jazzpunk without giving too much away? If you're aged between 28 - 40 and enjoy offbeat pop-culture references with no explanation (you just had to be there, man) this is the game for you. As soon as I started to play, the utter brilliance and absurdity seeped into my brain like a double shot of tequila. Relaxing and exhilarating at the same time, I’ve enjoyed every minute of this game. A true gem, bursting with experimentation, joy and creativity. Necrophone Games are testament to the old adage, “Build it and they will come” and like Kevin Costner in Field of Dreams, Necrophone listened to the voices in their heads and built a game unlike anything we’ve seen before, or will ever see again, and the people rejoiced. Get Jazzpunk, get comfortable and get ready for a good time.

Posted: February 21, 2014
												I imagine this game will end up (if it isn't already) generating some divided discussions, sort of like The Stanley Parable. In terms of plot length, the game is fairly short. However, there are dozens and dozens of unique assets and dialogue blips to entertain and even evoke a laugh. JAZZPUNK is exactly the kind of game I enjoy: simple gameplay, nonsensical plot, ridiculous situations, trippy art style, out of control soundtrack, and sharp humour. Playing this I feel every childish and random event is deliberate, and often pretty smart.Admittedly $15.00 may be a bit high for such a game, but it'll likely go on sale in the near future. And when it does, I recommend giving JAZZPUNK a shot

I can't even express my feelings--it's just really great, OK? Buy it. :D

Posted: November 7, 2014
												I just finished this game for the first time a moment ago and I can't seem to find the words that would properly describe my experience. So, instead, I will simply tell you about some of the things that I did in the game.> I ate vast quantities of jelly in order to fulfill my ethical obligations> I ran gleefully through the streets of a city, spraying strangers with pigeon pheromones and beheld the spectacle of the ensuing chaos. > I swatted Japanese people with a flyswatter, which resulted in them becoming blow flies and taking to the skies.> I explored the depths of cyberspace as represented by a 3D space suspended in an endless white void.> I cleaned a man's ears, with perhaps a little too much zeal, and was rewarded with a portion of his brain and sandwich -both of which were previously residing in his skull.> I threw a jar full of large, dangerous looking spiders in a man's face and suffered no ill-consequences for it.> I turned on an industrial blender which, for reasons unknown to me, was located in the bottom of a hot-tub, killing and processing the corpses of the four people who were inside and then served a portion of the bloody juices up to an unsuspecting woman who was terribly thirsty.> I snogged a homeless manThe game has an unremarkable story that shows glimpses of wanting to be a meta-commentary on things from time to time but is ultimately just mindlessly stupid (in a good way mind) and requires no real focus.7/10, a very memorable experience; buy when on special.

Posted: February 8, 2014
												The most carefully crafted nonsense I've ever played in my entire life. If I could describe this game in one word, it would be absurd. The humor hits more often than it misses, and there are tons of bad computer related puns, lots of Airplane/Naked Gun style humor, and a bunch of stuff that reminds me of Ren and Stimpy. If you're into dumb games then this is right in your wheelhouse.

Posted: March 3, 2014
												What can I say, this game works on so many levels. It's funny. You will be laughing. There are lots of shoutouts to lots of other stuff. If you are old enough that the game's retro mid-century aesthetic is what you remember from your childhood, even better. If you are familiar with some electrical engineering, there are vintage schematics and several very nerdy puns. If you remember The Cold War (the first one; as I am writing this Russia has just seized Crimea), even better. If you have been playing computer games since the MS-DOS days even better. If you are familiar with the Japanese and/or Russian languages, even better. If you are familiar with the names in the guestbook, even better.Even if you just arrived on this planet yesterday, you will really enjoy this game. Buy and play it and replay it and just soak in the atmosphere.

Posted: June 19, 2014
												After months passed after beating Jazzpunk, I wasn't completely comfortable recommending it. Even though I absolutely loved every second of it. But now, I think it's time to voice my thoughts on this game.Jazzpunk is a game that meets every desire I would want in a video game. It has one of the funniest senses of humor I've seen in a game. Baffling the player with surreal situations that, upon first playthrough, are absolutely unpredictable. However, this humor is not for everyone, and that's why I had trouble recommending it. For me, my god it's hilarious. But for most of my friends, and most people on Steam, it's probably not for them.Basically, I absolutely loved this game, and I will vouch for it for anyone with a love for surreal humor. Anyone else... not really. The only real problem I have with the game is that it's 15 dollars at the time that I write this. It doesn't seem like much of a difference, but I feel that 10 dollars is a more fitting price. See, I'm mostly okay with buying at full price, but not everyone will feel the same. So, if it's on sale: BUY BUY BUY! Unless you don't mind. I don't care. I'm not good at writing reviews. I'm sorry for wasting your time.

Posted: August 31, 2014
												Jazzpunk is a game where you walk around and do special missions! Which really shouldn't be taken seriously, as the game is all about doing funny missions, activities and coming across references. What attracted me is the art style of the world and the people, which all can be seen in first person.  I really enjoyed the humour in this game and it even made me laugh out loud several times. Even after a while playing the humour doesn't get predictable. The humour is mostly: cartoonish, absurd and goofy. Afterall I am happy that I have played Jazzpunk because there are not many games with an funny experience. The only two complaints I have is that after a while I didn't want to talk to random people in the game because they weren't that funny. And the other one is that the game only takes around 3 hours, Which may be for many people too few hours for the asking price. So those people can better wait for a sale.In short:A game where you walk around and encounter many funny activities, references, people and mini-games.

Posted: November 7, 2014
												I just finished this game for the first time a moment ago and I can't seem to find the words that would properly describe my experience. So, instead, I will simply tell you about some of the things that I did in the game.> I ate vast quantities of jelly in order to fulfill my ethical obligations> I ran gleefully through the streets of a city, spraying strangers with pigeon pheromones and beheld the spectacle of the ensuing chaos. > I swatted Japanese people with a flyswatter, which resulted in them becoming blow flies and taking to the skies.> I explored the depths of cyberspace as represented by a 3D space suspended in an endless white void.> I cleaned a man's ears, with perhaps a little too much zeal, and was rewarded with a portion of his brain and sandwich -both of which were previously residing in his skull.> I threw a jar full of large, dangerous looking spiders in a man's face and suffered no ill-consequences for it.> I turned on an industrial blender which, for reasons unknown to me, was located in the bottom of a hot-tub, killing and processing the corpses of the four people who were inside and then served a portion of the bloody juices up to an unsuspecting woman who was terribly thirsty.> I snogged a homeless manThe game has an unremarkable story that shows glimpses of wanting to be a meta-commentary on things from time to time but is ultimately just mindlessly stupid (in a good way mind) and requires no real focus.7/10, a very memorable experience; buy when on special.

												So, the most common negative side of this game I can see in the reviews is the length of this game. I completely disagree. You can play this game for way more than 2 hours. Posted: June 24, 2014
												An odd, surreal, colorful world, the first thing you'll notice about this game is just how creatively bizarre it is. It's strangely familiar with many of its elements and homages, and yet when it mixes them all up you still feel a breath of creativeness shine through. If you enjoyed things like old 60's cartoons or shows with their campiness, and love tongue in cheek humour, this is a great game for that. It also reminded me a bit of the Venture Bros., with the tone of everything satirizing and poking fun at the "cartoons of yesteryear".The humour and art direction are indeed the strongest points to this game. If you're looking for a plot, however, I would say this doesn't really have much of one, aside from glimpses of the world they live in. The writing is at its strongest with humour, which is what the game 100% is.Unfortunately, the game is very short, at most 2 hours, and not much replay value unless you like to experience it again after a long time or 100% the game. I recommend it solely off of the fact that it is an extremely funny game, but I would not pick it up for its full price of $15. Pick it up for when it's under $5, preferably around $3. It is well worth that price in broken sides and laughs alone.

Posted: March 24, 2015
												Take one part Get Smart, one part Warioware, a generous splash of Ren and Stimpy, liquify then shake well and what your left with is Jazzpunk. A wholly unique and incredibly fun game. It is, hands down, one of the best games I've played in ages. Considering how simple of a game it is that may seem like an exaggeration, but that's the truth. The entirety of the gameplay is essentially walking around and clicking on just about anything you can see. However, inside the simple gameplay is a wealth of humor and absurdism so abundant that it bursts through the simplicity to smack you in the face, leaving you asking for more. This is a really short game, I mean extremely so, and I would have loved for it to be longer. But really, there's so much packed into what little length there is that I know if I play through it again I'll find more goodies, side quests, and easter eggs that I didn't see the first few times around. I wholeheartedly recommend this game. I got this way below the asking price in a bundle, but it is more than worth the full fifteen dollars. If you can get it cheaper, then great, but consider buying it full price if you can't because it's a great game that everyone should try.

Posted: August 12, 2014
												Games like this are often not for everyone, and really it will come down to weather you're open to something new, different, but personally speaking, I went in not knowing much, and came out laughing, having explored every little nook and cranny the game has. The world has a strange, absurd stream of consciousness feel to it, with the odd musical score jittering throughout the game, I left feeling like this was a genuine attempt at being a little different and succeeding somewhat.I clocked in just two hours on it, so I'll let you decide if that's worth 10 pounds, but as of right now it's a mere 3 pounds and for that price I'd say it's absolutely worth it.

Posted: September 1, 2014
												Madcap, hilarious and weird. Mashes together cyberpunk, 50's/60's aesthetics, spy movies, and on-point video game references. Absurd and ridiculous sense of humor that is unpredictable but not stupidly random. Most of the jokes have amazing punchlines if you think about it enough. A good portion of this barrage of goofball antics are really ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ funny, and will leave a lingering snicker under your breath for the rest of the day.The gameplay is basic. The puzzles are generally solved through exploring the world, identifying things out of place and investigating. Minimal understanding of the game world's logic needs to be applied; your first instincts are usually right.I can't recommend this game enough. God bless this game and everyone who helped develop it.

Posted: September 22, 2014
												The, “are video-games art?” debate has to-date been hampered by one glaring issue. Every video-game people point to as a great example that they ARE art is, more or less, the same. Somebody who doesn't think video-games are art, and doesn't think Journey, Flower, and its' ilk are evidence to the contrary is probably not going to be swayed by examples of other games that are very similar to Journey and Flower. I really like those games, for the record. Enter Jazzpunk. This game is, at the core, an art game. The entire point of it is to explore the world, find interesting hidden stuff, and progress a very basic plot that takes you to new areas and new hidden stuff. Most things you interact with have no point, other than to tell a joke or show you a weird thing. The difference between this game and those other 'art' games is mostly one of tone, but it is different enough that I think people who hate Flower could easily love this. It removes the pretension from art games and grounds the genre in weird, cyber-cold-war trappings. It's genuinely hilarious. It, quite frankly, has grown up. Flower is the type of interactive art that a poetry major straight out of college would dream up. Jazzpunk, on the other hand, feels like it was made by some dude in his thirties who likes wrestling, eighties action movies, and Johnny Mnemonic. It has meat, and substance, and an actual identity that's all its' own. It has, quite literally, changed the game. From now on when I want to show a non-gamer an artsy-fartsy type interactive experience, it probably won't be Flower or Journey, as much as I like those games. It'll be Jazzpunk.

Posted: February 21, 2014
												I imagine this game will end up (if it isn't already) generating some divided discussions, sort of like The Stanley Parable. In terms of plot length, the game is fairly short. However, there are dozens and dozens of unique assets and dialogue blips to entertain and even evoke a laugh. JAZZPUNK is exactly the kind of game I enjoy: simple gameplay, nonsensical plot, ridiculous situations, trippy art style, out of control soundtrack, and sharp humour. Playing this I feel every childish and random event is deliberate, and often pretty smart.Admittedly $15.00 may be a bit high for such a game, but it'll likely go on sale in the near future. And when it does, I recommend giving JAZZPUNK a shot

Posted: February 19, 2014
												What can I say about Jazzpunk without giving too much away? If you're aged between 28 - 40 and enjoy offbeat pop-culture references with no explanation (you just had to be there, man) this is the game for you. As soon as I started to play, the utter brilliance and absurdity seeped into my brain like a double shot of tequila. Relaxing and exhilarating at the same time, I’ve enjoyed every minute of this game. A true gem, bursting with experimentation, joy and creativity. Necrophone Games are testament to the old adage, “Build it and they will come” and like Kevin Costner in Field of Dreams, Necrophone listened to the voices in their heads and built a game unlike anything we’ve seen before, or will ever see again, and the people rejoiced. Get Jazzpunk, get comfortable and get ready for a good time.

Posted: January 5, 2016
												BUY/SALE/PASS: Sale - Wait for a price dropPerhaps the closest video games will ever come to the cult classic comedy film ‘Airplane!’, Jazzpunk never fails to make any interaction with absolutely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ anything result in something that makes you laugh out loud whilst mired in a murky middle ground of confusion and amusement. Simple missions to infiltrate complexes and retrieve secret intel are spun out to also include such activities as guiding mind controlled pigeons, watching movies while armed with a bucket of popcorn to hurl at people further down the rows, and an outrageous shout-out to the best bonus game in Street Fighter history. Oh my car indeed.The vibrant-colored cartoony environments, the huge dialogue text, the restroom sign shaped characters, and the rapid fire jokes makes this first person adventure/descent into madness both fun and stylish. If you have ever laughed at the likes of comedy classics ‘Naked Gun’, ‘Hot Shots’, or ‘Kung Pow: Enter The Fist’, Jazzpunk is a fully worthy experience. Be confused. Be very confused.

Posted: March 3, 2014
												What can I say, this game works on so many levels. It's funny. You will be laughing. There are lots of shoutouts to lots of other stuff. If you are old enough that the game's retro mid-century aesthetic is what you remember from your childhood, even better. If you are familiar with some electrical engineering, there are vintage schematics and several very nerdy puns. If you remember The Cold War (the first one; as I am writing this Russia has just seized Crimea), even better. If you have been playing computer games since the MS-DOS days even better. If you are familiar with the Japanese and/or Russian languages, even better. If you are familiar with the names in the guestbook, even better.Even if you just arrived on this planet yesterday, you will really enjoy this game. Buy and play it and replay it and just soak in the atmosphere.

Posted: September 27, 2015
												"Jazzpunk is a comedy adventure set in an alternate reality Cold War World, plagued with corporate espionage, CyberCrime, and sentient martinis. Gameplay is inspired by spoof comedy films and cartoons of yesteryear, with a focus on weird gadgets, exotic locales, and open-world style exploration." -Please read the entirety of the review for all considerations-The Cold War era and corporate-espionage themes are nice and not common in games. There is, mixed in, a world where technological integration and a feeling of publicity in every action taken is felt. The locations visited in the game, especially if they are actually named their alternative national names (in a 'mission' where you fly to your location) are a nice variety.That being said, for the gameplay; there is a good amount to see on each level and a nice artistic style. While the levels are decent, they tend to be relatively short considering how many levels there are in the game. With a dozen or so levels (there I told you how many there are): some can be completed in a manner of minutes- even one that can be completed in seconds (the 'mission' where you fly to your location). This game relies on the side-missions or exploring the locations to add gameplay, as doing the objective straight-forward results in a even-moreso short game.The game story is spy-ish and that's nice and all, but with little context as to what you are actually doing and an ending that says "this could be explained later" but, as of September 2015, has no additional missions or follow-up.For 15 US dollars, this game is short in gameplay and (frankly) not a high gameplay-to-dollar ratio. I have, as of this review, 3.1 hours into the game: and that includes two runs of the entire game, exploring the entirety of each map; playing the joke mini-games, like Wedding Qake, several times; and replaying select levels to do all the mini-games over again, like the "boss level" and the "vacation resort" locations.That being said, for the good quality and detail and fun this game has, for 15 dollars I would not recommend this game until, either, there is a sale or some sort of additional gameplay bundled with it.

Posted: January 10, 2015
AUDIOBad VibesVISUALSurrealDIFFICULTYGlitchyVIBESurrealCRAVINGExperimentalON SALEOccasionallyPROS: As someone who is enamoured with surrealism, this kept my attention through to the very end. It is fashioned like LSD: Dream Simulator for PSX. Levels are dream-like in consistency and style, while sound serves to bemuse and disorient.CONS: Difficulty seesaws illogically. FOV is messed up; at best, you will constantly be butting into things. At worst, you will get motion sickness. Final level is not designed well, making it inordinantly-laggy. Too short for it's undiscounted asking price. The artistic direction is tops, but the actual game design is amateur.WORTH: It's not worth $15.00 USD, plain and simple. A fair amount of my hours came from walkthrough creation, you can expect to beat this game in less than four hours. It sees the occasional sale, but only during the major holidays.OVERALL: Jazzpunk has heavy goals involving "alternate reality Cold War Cyber-Crime Espionage" that fall hilariously flat, but it's comedic eyecandy and worth a night of drunkplay with that distinguishable Adult Swim style. SCORE: 7/10                                                                     Full Review Coming Soon

Posted: July 18, 2015
												I really wasn't sure what to make of this game. I'll admit that it was an impulse buy. The trailer for the game was intriguing, although not necessarily indicative of the actual game. But for the cost I thought I would try it out.What I really like out this game is that it's really good at poking fun at everyone. I found myself laughing at inside jokes from my childhood, i.e. Ninja Turtles, SW, old school Quake, Street Fighter, Twister......I mean the list goes on and on. It also pokes fun at modern society, medicine, and morality without being too tongue in cheek.The achievements are relatively easy to obtain. The gameplay is also not overly complex. As an added bonus there are mini games scattered throughout the campaign. My biggest disappointment with this game is that it is quite short, and even a long run thru will only last you maybe 2 hours. It also desperately needs a sequel. It's not terribly expensive, but if you get it at a good price then I think that it is worth buying. It's a fun and funny game. I would love to see a successor to this, with new jokes, trippy missions, and outrageous mini games. Timmah says: 12/"It's meant to be quite good"

Posted: June 28, 2014
												Jazzpunk was born from an alternate reality in which Leslie Nielsen did not die and instead became an adventure game designer. Quirky, bizarre, disorienting, and hilarious from the opening cutscene to the final fade to black, Jazzpunk has to be seen to be believed. Most of the obstacles are simple to overcome and the game can be finished in a single sitting, but it's all about the journey in Jazzpunk. Walking around, poking everything just to see what happens, and then rubbing your eyes in disbelief when you see the results.It's an experience that I was sad to see end, but it's brief stay on my computer screen made it's impact all the more potent.If you have no qualms about spending money on a short interactive comedy then definitely pick up Jazzpunk. It'll provide fourth degree burns all over your face.

Posted: November 11, 2014
												Jazzpunk is a brief but hilarious indie game full of non sequiturs and espionage. After finishing the game in the 3 hours it takes to complete it would seem like a reasonable guess that I could have something to say about this game. Unfortunately this game has the unique quality of being completely indescribable. What is accomplished between the start and the end of this game is not something that can be put into words, and attempting to do so would destroy what makes Jazzpunk so great. I suggest anyone who has the time and money to play this game to get it if only to show the world that taking risks and making unique experiences is important.

Posted: December 13, 2015
												8/10What to say about Jazzpunk? It's a blast in every way possible.Ok, the world is limited and the graphics are basic. Who cares? The personality and originality of this game surpasses any other. Set during the Cold War, it's a mockery of conspiracy and the fear of new technology that abounded in that era.You enter each level by taking pills, then you have to solve the puzzles using the craziest interactions possible to discover who the bad guy is. There is plenty to explore in each level that doesn't have to do with the main story.By the way, this game predicted ebola.Fun includes: Zapping pigeons, killing pizza, turning on the fire and ice alarms, playing WeddingQuake, putting as much makeup on as you want, catching a robotic pig, racing gravy dishes, killing someone in a pillowfight, and getting eaten by a crocodile  (or is it an alligator?)

												Jazzpunk is more than a game, it's an experience. While one could presumably speed through the game in under 2 hours, the point of the game is not to simply find the exit. Jazzpunk is best experienced at a slow pace. Just like the best point-and-click adventure games, Jazzpunk encourages you to poke around in all corners and explore every option. If you're someone who wants to see the Ren and Stimpy philosophy in action, Jazzpunk is for you.

Posted: February 21, 2014
												I love quirky, unique, off-the-wall games and was really looking forward to Jazzpunk based on the reviews. What I got, however, was a game with an incoherent story, painfully dull core mechanics, uninteresting objectives and scattershot "trying-too-hard" humor that doesn't work for me at all. Perhaps the last point is a cultural or age-based issue since I'm English and now into my 40's, but I found nothing funny about the game at all. The reviews that Jazzpunk is getting suggests that it definitely has an audience out there, but it's clearly not me. I would suggest taking a peek at some videos before buying in order to make sure that it's the sort of experience that's going to work for you.

Posted: February 11, 2014
												Ehhhh... I would have recommended this if it was cheaper, but for 12€ you get 2-3 hours (this including most of the side activities and achivements) of comedy that ranges from actually funny to "that was supposed to be funny?", which I realise is hard to avoid with a game that is completely built on comedy, but while a game like The Stanley Parable managed to be funny time after time, the jokes here aren't very fun on replay if at all. The gameplay is also a bit on the iffy side, which for a "walk and interact with stuff" kind of game is hard to defend, with the walking in the game feeling floaty and sluggish, and there just isn't enough varriation in fun things to happen when clicking around. The sound design is also rather bad with music that is downright depressing and droning, and overdone robot effects on voices which sometimes makes it hard to actually understand what is being said.If you see this on a really cheap sale and want to see a game build itself entierly on crazy random comedy, then sure, do pick it up, but it's simply not worth more than 5€ in my opinion when there isn't a lot of content to be had, with only 3 actual big levels.

Posted: December 29, 2015
												This game is incredible. First of all, it's absolutely gorgeous in the most retro/♥♥♥♥♥♥/stylized/STRANGE way??? Which I love. The trailers and intro to the game are gorgeous, and from the moment you step out of your person-shapped luggage case, there's a lot to explore and look at (talk to the box). It's definitely not the longest game by any means, but it's jam-packed with humor and is by far the most surreal game I've ever had the enjoyment of playing. The NPCs have some hilarious lines, the levels are full of strange side missions and stuff to interact with and there are even a few minigames to find. Everything is so surreal and it breaks the fourth wall a lot and it's so random I JUST LOVE IT SO MUCH. You can wack people with a fly swatter why would you not buy this

Posted: November 30, 2014
												This game is absolutely fantastic. It requires some thinking, sense of humor, and curiosity to get the most out of it though. There are many minigames, side quests, and hilarious tasks that make up the bulk of this game, as you can beat the main story in a very short amount of time. Even though it's only about 2-3 hours if you play it the way I do (just looking around each stage to find whatever I can, but not caring enough to find everything.), this game is just WAY too good to miss out on. Posted: June 21, 2015
												Jazzpunk is really great. It's the kind of game the Zucker Brothers (Airplane, The Naked Gun) would make if they were around and playing games during the Nintendo 64 era. The humor is mostly really really silly, but there's so many gags thrown in there that eventually one will pop up that really makes you laugh. The whole game feels more like a fun toy than a game with a well defined structure. Most of the areas have lots and lots of optional things to play with or people to get dialogue from. There's almost nothing else out there like Jazzpunk, and I wish I could play it all over again without knowing the gags. I recommend it.

Posted: December 4, 2014
												Did you play any of those Living Books games as a kid? Did you compulsively click on every single thing to see the wacky funny stuff happen? Do you tire of "comedy" adventure games just having the character make some pithy comment whenever you try to click on something that's not story-related and wish those things actually, you know, did stuff?Welcome to Jazzpunk, a game designed exactly for people like you! The campaign is short and simple, but the missions are packed with sidequests, minigames, and wacky interactababable objects and characters (who may or may not also be objects). Click all the things! Get all the achievements! For once it'll actually be worthwhile! But be warned: You'll wish it was longer, and it might just ruin traditional adventure games for you forever.

Posted: December 5, 2014
												If you like the type of humor found in Adult Swim, you will surely enjoy this game.If you don't know if you would like the type of humor found in Adult Swim, go look up "Robot Chicken" or "Aqua Teen Hunger Force." I'll wait.If you didn't like that, you might not enjoy this game too much. Maybe you should go buy a different game.If you thought it was at all funny, Jazzpunk will be worth your time. The gameplay is nothing amazing. It's just a lot of humor, references, jokes, and fun. To me, it was worth every second I played it. Massively entertaining. Even the end credits were fun.On the other hand, it is quite short, and it might not be worth full price. Get it on sale, or in a bundle, and enjoy.

Posted: February 22, 2015
												It's very damn short and i am glad i didn't pay full price for this game and only had to spend 4 bucks on it. Anyway, i really enjoyed this game, visually wise and humor wise. It usually takes alot that an indie game makes me laugh when it atempts humor, and while i didn't laughed out loud once, i got a few chuckles out of it sometimes and found some things pretty funny or amusing, and even that is an accomplishment alone, which i command Jazzpunk for. Otherwise, the whole setting is pretty cool and bizarre, sorta like a take on Soviet Russia, Japan, Cyberpunk and whatnot. I like bizarre/weird Settings anyway so this was a big plus in my book in the first place. I am pretty glad the game is as long as it is, if it would have been longer, i don't think i would have enjoyed it as much after some time. Besides the main game you have short, but nice little minigames to and the also  alot of dialoge with the characters and/or the enviroment itself. If you rush the game and don't talk to anybody, you will be done in an hour i guess, but if you take your time and basically explore everything you get a good few hours counting, atleast for me it didOnce again, i can recommend it, one of the few indiegames i like out there. For what it basically is though, i can't recommend it for the 15 € (or dollar) pricetag.

Posted: February 24, 2015
												What could have been a really interesting and engrossing experience just left me feeling like I'd been lied to. You know all that kooky stuff you see in the trailer, that sets you up for a super psychadelic experience? Yeah, pretty much none of it actually happens in the game. No using turtles, no flying brains, and the skycar section is literally about 10 seconds long and basically on rails. It's good for what it is, but the trailer is just flat-out dishonest and you'll breeze through this in an hour and a half. Get it on a sale.

Posted: February 21, 2014
												I love quirky, unique, off-the-wall games and was really looking forward to Jazzpunk based on the reviews. What I got, however, was a game with an incoherent story, painfully dull core mechanics, uninteresting objectives and scattershot "trying-too-hard" humor that doesn't work for me at all. Perhaps the last point is a cultural or age-based issue since I'm English and now into my 40's, but I found nothing funny about the game at all. The reviews that Jazzpunk is getting suggests that it definitely has an audience out there, but it's clearly not me. I would suggest taking a peek at some videos before buying in order to make sure that it's the sort of experience that's going to work for you.

Posted: December 2, 2014
												Le sigh. Well, this game was funny-ish (how many electronic/software/computer puns can you fit into one scene?). Very charming, retro-chic style and music (the music is the best part). Makes me wish I was a high-roller sales exec in the 50s, when flying and traveling were still cool.But other than the massive nostalgia blast, kind of not fun as a GAME. Lots of near-chuckle moments, almost no laughing. A single digit number of gross-out/creep-out moments. Jazzpunk really wants to be Maniac Mansion or Day or the Tentacle, or some other adventure game that really knows how to bring the funny, but those games it ain't. I got this as part of a bundle from another distributor that shall not be named. Glad I did, otherwise I'd have been annoyed at how short the game was. (A lot of my recorded game time was just pausing the game to go do something else). If you watch a playthrough, it's as fun as doing it yourself. So don't buy this game. Because you have better things to do. Like, anything.I'm telling you, if you buy this game and finish it after reading this review, you'll be like, "Man, I wish I had listened to that reviewer guy, he was right." Last chance? Fine, whatever, get the game, I don't care. I just felt super-stupid finishing it, and I'm only telling you now so you won't have to suffer the shame and regret that I did. Cheers!

Posted: April 9
												The game is very short, but that is forgiven by the sheer amount of gold level comedy in every corner, had a good laugh on several stages throughout the game, specially when you complete certain achievements, where the game truly shines.Many people are saying it's price point is rather steep, but if you can get it during a sale, I see no reason why you shouldn't set off about 3 hours during a day and give this one a go.

Posted: April 23
												Jazzpunk is one of those diamonds in the rough that you find once in a while, although it isn't the longest game out there, it still has a lot of fun and hilarious content packed into it. i found myself wanting so much more from the game after i got to the end.You start the game as Polyblank and from the intro credits video it shows you are being shipped somewhere in a human shaped suitcase. Another example of the different style of comedy this game portrays.I wasn't invested with the story as i was too taken by what was happening at that moment in time. One second it's sitting in a room reading comedic hospital booklets, next it's swatting flies in a vase shop. The game always has you knowing that something funny can and will happen. So i never really payed attention to the story as much as i should, but i did gather that You're an agent for some agency that has their headquarters in a seemingly abandoned subway station, from the way the game is and its style it feels like its 1950's to 1960's era. but you talk to "The Director" in the organisation and he assigns you to do these James Bond style of missions. The missions start after you take "Missionoyl" pills which i found quite humorous.You need to save the director who gets kidnapped near the end which came with some funny yet new ways of comedy.The game has an mix of looking both cartoon and drawn, it really sets it apart from a lot of other games. the game-play makes it much more exciting to explore instead of going straight to the objective, the game will be quite short if the player just went for the objective, but as do any games the side quests tend to bulk it up. But as much exploring i did, and i tried to see everything, it still felt rather short as i completed the game in just 3 hours. It left me wanting a lot more of whatever charm that Jazzpunk had.I really enjoyed Jazzpunk, i hope that whenever Jazzpunk 2 or similar comes out that it keeps me as humoured as Jazzpunk9/10 Love It

Posted: November 28, 2016
												This is less of a "Game" and more of an experience.  And that's a shame because at it's pricepoint I figured it would be at least worth some puzzle solving akin to the days of point and click adventure games.  But not really, anything puizzling is pretty much linear.  There are lots of secrets, but it's really only about searching different areas until something funny happens.  If there was more "Meat" to this game (Puzzles and the like) I could reccomend it.  But honestly as a comedy piece it's not worth playing through a mere four levels for this level of strangeness.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												If this game was a meal it would be one from one of those take-away places where the menu has a picture that makes it look like Heston Blumenthal works in the kitchen but what you get is a brown paper bag with a passable burger and some listless fries.Let's try and concoct a genre tag for this one. Interactive pun simulator? Burroughs-em-up? It's a distracting and fairly enjoyable little thing, but this is ultimately a once only experience. I wouldn't recommend dropping more than £5 on this if you can avoid it given a loose £/hr enjoyment ratio you can get everywhere else.I'm all for doing something a bit different within the concept of a 'game'. What Jazzpunk provides is an on-rails 'experience' telling a somewhat surreal story laced with puns and references to hard-boiled detective fiction and gaming staples and offering up a few puzzles to solve on the way.Whilst never exactly actively bad it does suffer from being overly drawn out in places and the general pacing feels a little disjointed. The puzzles seem to actually get less difficult as the story progresses, perhaps this was a intentional 'thing' but if so the point of it was lost on me.If you've played games long enough to anticipate some of the usual game design language (the items hidden in the bind corner, if the game points you left have a quick look to the right, pull the lever that appears to do nothing etc) then don't bother chasing after the intriguing possibilities in Jazzpunk. There a lot of hidings to nothing to waste your time on for no reward.I really am trying to be positive about this game, I'm giving it a thumbs up because it's not actiively awful.What there is is very nicely made, there's nothing technically wrong with it, but ultimately when reaching the end I was just left with a general feeling of "Oh. Well that happened. Next!".

I managed to complete the game and got almost every achievement on my first playthrough on 3 hours, the 0.4 hours was just getting the last three-four achievements I needed to complete the game.The fun is in finding all the hidden secrets and easter eggs, such as the 'Wedding Quake' minigame and a couple of others, in which you'll surely rack up some extra hours spent searching for these fun little things.Overall, I really recommend this game, despite being a bit short for my liking, I really enjoyed all the little things you can do in the game and all the bad puns that came along with it.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												In my short time with this game I've infiltrated the Soviet Embassy, devoured countless pharmaceuticals, committed insurance fraud, played miniature golf, stolen a top secret cybernetic kidney, and boxed a sedan to the death. Jazzpunk is filled to the brim with personality, humor, and enough WTF moments to make even the most seasoned adventure gamer blush. The setting alone is worth the price of admission; Imagine Mad Men meets Blade Runner written by the folks who brought you Airplane and directed by Tim Schafer. Sure, it may only clocks in at four hours; but it never ceases to be utterly engrossing as well as hilarious. I've not played something so memorable, so provocative, so weird as this in quite some time. If you're a fan of spy movies, satire, adventure games, cyberpunk, copious amounts of alcohol, or simply want a fresh experience then JazzPunk is your most certainly for you.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												A while back, when I saw the trailer for "Thirty Flights of Loving", I was excited by the abstract, highly stylish visuals.  It looked like a seriously unique, undeniably "indie" experience, and I couldn't wait to get my hands on it. Players heaped praise on the game, finding deep meaning inside the painfully short experience.  I was not one of those people, unfortunately.  I found "Thirty Flights..." to be a shallow proof of concept, at best -- something the developer himself seemed to admit from the commentary track.  I walked away from the game bitter, having felt duped by popular opinion.That said, I very much liked the IDEA of "Thirty Flights": an interactive book.  A way of telling a unique, linear story, letting the player guide the narrative along at their own pace.  (Adding VR into the mix will take this immersive idea even further, but I'm getting ahead of myself.)  As it turns out, the game I was hoping "Thirty Flights" would be, is what "Jazzpunk" actually *IS*.  Both games are very strange, unique, linear short stories, but "Jazzpunk" gives you a bit more freedom to explore, with side-quests and mini-games here and there along the way.  What separates the two further, is that "Jazzpunk" is straight up hilarious and wonderfully strange.  More times than I can count, I found myself wide-eyed, staring at the monitor and going "whaaat!" with a huge smile.Additionally, there are numerous references, both popular and obscure, to old technology (Captain Crunch's famous 2600 whistle, for example), and the culture around them.  Raymond Scott's unmistakable trademark musical style heavily influences the proceedings (not to mention directly referenced here and there).While I damned "Thirty Flights" for being criminally short for the price, I found "Jazzpunk"'s short length to be JUST long enough without overstaying it's welcome.  A $10 pricetag would probably be more comfortable than $15, but the effort and love that was clearly put into this...well, I wouldn't at all feel ripped off if I'd paid full price.I'd absolutely love to see this expanded into an ongoing series, with each installment being just as short but sweet.4/5

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
A Paladin's Steam Review: Jazzpunk. Is This Memes? Or Just Complete Nonsense?Genre: 1st Person Surreal I-Haven't-Done-Enough-Drugs-For-This Adventure.Developed & Published by: Necrophone Games & Adult Swim Games. Platform: Windows, Mac, LinuxBusiness Model: Base Game.Copy Purchased by Myself PreambleI can’t help but feel that the title of this game is more than a bit apt to describe the experience I had with this game. This game makes no sense from a story perspective. If this is what tripping on drugs is even remotely like, I don’t think I want to ever experience the real thing. I’m not even going to try and describe the story or the purpose you play in this game because even I’m not certain what the purpose of this game is supposed to serve. Oh right, a comedy adventure. Overall Gameplay ThoughtsReviewing a game's comedy is a very dangerous road to walk on. What I find funny isn't what you'll find funny and vice versa. I stay away from talking about a game's humor and generalize what it's like. You may find this incredibly hilarious while it's all completely lost on me. So, I’ll just break it down to its parts. What you’re essentially getting is a collection of unremarkable (or boring) mini-games with walking sequences between them. During the entire time you will be subjected to a multitude of references and jokes from various forms of media that you may or may not get. (Prepare to not get a lot of them). This style of game has been rising in popularity of late and frankly, it hasn't been my favorite to play. Which this entry has only further cemented my dislike of it. PC Settings & OptionsJazzpunk comes with resolution options, control bindings and more. However, it should be noted that the game will override your mouse + keyboard for the controller every time you start up the game. Field of View slider is missing (from a First Person game no less). What you’re left with is a quality slider, v-sync & mouse options. Optimization seemed fine (its not terribly demanding) and it never crashed on me. That said, I noticed that my camera was really jerky/jittery when you moved it around. Never figured out why. Final ThoughtsIt’s hard to find these games enjoyable when the interactive parts are meager and the jokes are lost on me. Obviously I got a few of them but when a world refuses to take itself seriously, you have to wonder if everything is trying to be a reference. Is the walkway a reference or did what that character said behind me supposed to be a reference? Or is it actually relevant to the plot?! I can't tell! The references are extremely broad too so it's hard to place where they're coming from half the time. Is it supposed to be an homage to some other TV series and what is that or why am I flying upside to, idk, something and augh and gah this game is….…..ultimately frustrating.Read this review and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]

Too long; didn't watch -- Though there's not much here in terms of gameplay and the ending feels fairly abrupt, Jazzpunk's self-aware humour and general sense of personality definitely makes it worth playing.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												Jazzpunk is quite unique.  It's really fun to look at, it's odd and absurd, which is great, but for me it goes nowhere with it. I am going to give it a thumbs down because: 1) It takes no effort or thought to play.  I have clicked everything, played all the mini games, searched every corner, gotten all the achievements and feel like I didn't do anything worthwhile when all is said and done.  2) The humor was not my kind of humor and it's unrelenting.  That's a problem since humor seems to be half the game content (the other half are the visuals).  For the most part, it is a continuous stream of computer-geek puns. IE: You go into a restaurant and the waitress says "I will be your dedicated server."  Lots and LOTS of that. There is almost no dialogue per se, just a lot of word play.  3) The game made me feel ill which really surprised me.  If you play for more than 30 minutes in a go, especially after the first chapter, most likely you will end up with a degree of motion sickness no matter how rarely you get it in real life.  This game could probably be weaponized for that ability.  4) The game is very very short, though given everything else, that is sort of a plus.  I kept expecting something in the game to wow me, to grab me mentally at least once, but nothing ever did.  It's colorful fluff.  If you like computer puns and pure silliness -- you'll probably have a great time.  If you want more from a game than just being taken on a ride, or if puns make you roll your eyes and sigh in annoyance -- then you probably want to give the game a miss.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												More information here: http://www.brokencartridge.net/games/review-jazzpunk/ (features a video review!)You will laugh, you will cry, but mostly you will be confused. Jazzpunk is an avant-garde comedy adventure inspired by spoof films and old slapstick cartoons. In this cyberpunk style world with an alternate reality Cold War theme, you are some type of spy or investigative agent. You are sent on missions finding cases of corporate espionage and “CyberCrime” in an open world.Jazzpunk will leave you scratching your head as much as it will be making you laugh. Each level has a main mission you must accomplish, but that is just the surface of what the game is all about. Expecting the unexpected will do you no good as you will still be absolutely bewildered at what lies behind every corner. Find a pizza box next to an old bum in the street corner? Open it and find that it brings you to another pizza world where you must kill pizza zombies with your oversized pizza pan and cutter. Surprises like that are waiting for you behind nearly every intractable object.A large amount of content in the game is not mandatory for completion, but that is what makes it so great.  You feel the impulse to cover every inch of each area to ensure that everything is experienced, because it is definitely worth exploring. Maybe you will steal the entry ticket to the hotel rooms, and in one you will find a bride and groom with their wedding cake that transports you into a wedding edition of Quake, or possibly have sex with a robot ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. The possibilities and expectations are endless and worth every moment.One thing I quickly realized is that there is no sense of challenge throughout the entire game. Essentially there is no way to fail or do something wrong. While this insures that you will never have to do the same thing twice or the hear same joke multiple times, it also removed some depth to certain scenes. Comedy is the game’s forte, which is great in its own sense but ends up revoking any type of challenge the game could possibly offer. If that is good or bad depends on the player, but it is definitely something worth noting.Even though I took my time trying to explore as much as possible, I still beat the game within 3 hours. That was slightly disappointing seeing how it is a 15 dollar title. Playing the game through multiple times is advised, because there will definitely be things that you missed. I would have liked to see a few more levels packed in there, though. I actually had an interest in the story and where it was going, but in retrospect is was a very short one. The game had some minor technical issues as well, such as crashing when trying to mess with the video settings in game. It wasn’t dual monitor friendly, either. I ended up having to use a control to properly play the game, which is still fine because it is perfectly playable with the standard Xbox controller, but let that be a warning to dual monitor users out there that you may have a few issues.Jazzpunk is an excellent game with a grand sense of humor and a unique style of play. We’ve never seen anything like it, and I doubt we ever will again. It shows that sometimes all we need is something different slapped onto our face. Adult Swim’s streak of publishing interesting games continues.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
Full review at: http://www.mode486.com/jazzpunk-review/Jazzpunk is an amazing comedic adventure. It’s funny, fun, entertaining and just a fantastic overall game. It has almost no flaws aside from being a three-hour experience, but that’s okay since the game only costs $15. I love everything about Jazzpunk and I feel that it’s probably one of the contenders for game of the year or at least indie game of the year. There’s simply nothing like it currently, and I’m glad. It’s a very unique experience that you truly will not find anywhere else.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												I absolutely love this game in a way I wasn't expecting.It has the right amount of humour and always in places you never expect to find it. You never know what you're going to come up against next, but you're guaranteed to laugh. Of course you could probably run straight through the game, do the tasks and finish it, but then you'd miss everything else going on. It's a game where you feel rewarded by looking at every little detail because so much of it has extra things to offer. It's not all in your face either, constantly forcing you to be in a typical funny situation. In fact a lot of the comedy in the game is quite subtle and you have to steer from the path in order to find it, but it makes you appreciate it as you play through. The attention to comedic detail is quite marvelous.The gameplay is nice and simple. You walk around, interact with objects in often fun and ingenious ways to complete puzzles and make your way through the story. The graphics are very cartoony but still maintains a great atmosphere with all the music and extra sounds going on. It suits the tone of the game perfectly.It's something nice, different and random. Nothing like I have played before and definitely a great experience. Would recommend.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												Full review: http://www.cublikefoot.com/review/jazzpunk-game-review/Well, this was one of the more interesting titles I’ve played of late. Certainly one of the most humorous games I’ve played in my life, that’s for sure. There’s just so many things right about Jazzpunk.Jazzpunk is a first-person comedy-adventure game set during the cold war, in an alternate reality. The game places large emphasis on open-world exploration, which can be seen immediately in the first level. I spent the majority of my time in the game exploring, rather than actually playing through the main story, although I did manage to beat the entire game in about two hours. The game’s length being my major complaint. For such a great game, I’d like more than just two hours.Unique. If I had to use one word to describe Jazzpunk, that’d be it. The game is full of references, side quests, and plenty of areas to explore in the various chapters. I even helped clean a guy’s massive ear out when he was unable to hear. Just one of the silly things that can be accomplished within the several chapters. Oh, and the dialogue. Fantastic. Simply fantastic. A lot of the characters in-game spoke like robots and it seemed like there were new accents everywhere I went.Jazzpunk is heavy on its comedic appeal. There are several instances in the game that serve no purpose other than to make you laugh. I ran into a shop at one point whose door simply said “closed for no reason”. There’s plenty of new things to find when exploring the worlds of each chapter, and, like I said, that’s where I had spent most of my playtime, looking around. It’s overwhelming at times, the amount of stuff that you can find whilst exploring.The game uses an interesting art style. I want to say its cel-shaded, but I don’t know if that’d be correct. For the most part, it does look like its cel-shaded, which is always a art style. Nothing to complain about in terms of the game’s graphics.If you’re going to pick up Jazzpunk, don’t expect much in terms of length if you just play through the game’s story. Instead, spend some time exploring about. You’ll find yourself laughing at the numerous scenes scattered throughout the game.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												This takes me back to my childhood, playing adventure games, Point and clicks, Grim Fandango, Indiana Jones, Lucas Arts. I loved it from start to finish, I`ve just played through it and I`m considering playing it again just to get all the achievments. I can`t remember the last time I felt that way after playing a game, but its been a while.The characters and the universe is charming, the controls are easy and the story is fun. The whole cold war spy thing was a great setting and the music suits that theme brilliantly. Wacky, intelligent, and entertaining. I think I recognised one of the bar patrons ;) kudos Necrophone. Only minus I can seem to find is that the game was a bit short, but I do prefer a short quality game over a long game where you can see the story dabbing off and becoming dull.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Hilarious! Art! These two words are ones almost never in the same sentence together, which is why I separated them with exclamation points. Separated or not though, Jazzpunk is both of these things.But to get to the point, (before I start talking about the weather or something, which i'm sure is nice where you live (if not, then I'm sure it's not nice (that is to say, I'm sure the weather is well weathered where you live (that really isn't what I was trying to say, but the 'weather is well weathered' pun is demonstrating the type of joke that can be found within Jazzpunk (You're welcome!))))) the real brilliance of Jazzpunk is how it frequently allows the player to transcend the main narrative in favour of allowing pointless exploration. The game itself is really more about the funny* hidden jokes than the silly storyline. So I only recommend this game if you have the patience to examine every little thing you come across. Or if you are an achievement hound. Because the achievements in this game are both numerous and drop-dead easy.All in all, I had a great time with this title! 9/10!*I take no responsibility for any un-funny jokes you come across. If you do come across an un-funny joke, don't message me with hate-mail telling me how much of a lying fool I am; instead take a step back** and re-evaluate your life.*** Look out the window! Watch the people outside swinging from tree to tree!**** Is it really worth the effort complaining to me!? The guy who will just delete your carefully worded hate message? And more importantly, maybe take a closer look and see if the joke you were complaining about is even really a joke! Not everything is you know. Unlike your life.*** #ohsnap**Do NOT do this if you are standing on the edge of a cliff.***I write this based on the assumtion that you actually have a life. My apologies if I have misjudged you.****I write this based on the assumption that you live in an alternate universe where everyone is obsessed with George of the Jungle and favours vines and trees over cars and trains. My apoligies if I have misjudged you.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Hilarious! Art! These two words are ones almost never in the same sentence together, which is why I separated them with exclamation points. Separated or not though, Jazzpunk is both of these things.But to get to the point, (before I start talking about the weather or something, which i'm sure is nice where you live (if not, then I'm sure it's not nice (that is to say, I'm sure the weather is well weathered where you live (that really isn't what I was trying to say, but the 'weather is well weathered' pun is demonstrating the type of joke that can be found within Jazzpunk (You're welcome!))))) the real brilliance of Jazzpunk is how it frequently allows the player to transcend the main narrative in favour of allowing pointless exploration. The game itself is really more about the funny* hidden jokes than the silly storyline. So I only recommend this game if you have the patience to examine every little thing you come across. Or if you are an achievement hound. Because the achievements in this game are both numerous and drop-dead easy.All in all, I had a great time with this title! 9/10!*I take no responsibility for any un-funny jokes you come across. If you do come across an un-funny joke, don't message me with hate-mail telling me how much of a lying fool I am; instead take a step back** and re-evaluate your life.*** Look out the window! Watch the people outside swinging from tree to tree!**** Is it really worth the effort complaining to me!? The guy who will just delete your carefully worded hate message? And more importantly, maybe take a closer look and see if the joke you were complaining about is even really a joke! Not everything is you know. Unlike your life.*** #ohsnap**Do NOT do this if you are standing on the edge of a cliff.***I write this based on the assumtion that you actually have a life. My apologies if I have misjudged you.****I write this based on the assumption that you live in an alternate universe where everyone is obsessed with George of the Jungle and favours vines and trees over cars and trains. My apoligies if I have misjudged you.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												Watching 10 minutes of Jazzpunk will let you know whether it's for you or not. Its brand of humour is hyper-specific, trading on James Bond, conspiracy theories, William Gibson and a dash of Blendo Games' work. If that type of humour appeals to you then stop reading, buy Jazzpunk, play Jazzpunk.Jazzpunk may be the funniest game I've ever played. Humour is brutally difficult in games because the player is in control of the timing. Jazzpunk nails it, almost effortlessly. It's a game that rewards you poking at everything, and everything you poke is guaranteed to have a joke attached. The concentration of lunacy is consistently dense. The number of jokes per square metre in this game is ridiculous. There's so much to find and so much to discover. A few jokes fall flat but the majority of them work and work well.Jazzpunk is essentially an adventure game. Often you'll be asked to collect certain items to combine with other items to progress. It sounds dull but virtually every puzzle is a clever joke or a stupid premise. Jazzpunk's objectives embrace the non-sequiter and the punchline and weave them into everything you do.Remember bubsy3d.com? Recall the end scene? Remember the Applebees? Jazzpunk's puzzles and easter eggs rival that moment in their sheer audacity every two minutes.It took some incredibly intelligent people to make a game that's so smart about being dumb. Even if it seems like it's not for you, you should play this game. It's a delight.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												Ok, i have had polarizing opinions on this game, but here goes.When you first start the game, you're greeted by attempting to infiltrate the Soviet Consulate. And then, as you're about to go up, you're greeted by a guy who tells you to go find a mailbox with chalk on the side, which you can ignore or follow. (There's no prompt to do so.) On my first playthrough i ignored, and i was greeted by a boring fetch mission with a glitchy dial phone, which then lead to a pretty boring game, purely because i put no time into it. It was short and un-appetizing, and the humor almost felt juvenile. But, on the second playthrough, i decided to follow the things the NPCs told me and i had a ♥♥♥♥ing blast. The side missions easily added 3 times the game's face value, and all the side missions and easter eggs felt actually funny. So, that's it.8/10, please follow the side missions for a much superior experience.Also, there is a parody of Quake called Wedding Qake built in, it's fantastic and addicting. Wedding Qake: 8/10, lack of options.

number of helpful: 11 of 22 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												Jazzpunk is another game that, like Zeno Clash, tries to be held up entirely by weirdness.  It fails just as spectacularly.  Behind the extreme weirdness, there is nothing interesting nor compelling just a bland game full of random occurences and random references.  I would liken it to the recent teenage buzzword "random":  It feels like a desperate cry for attention by being different when in reality it's rather predictable and not the least bit interesting.Gameplay consists of walking around and interacting with various objects and completing very short side missions while you accomplish your main objective for each level.  There are only a couple missions and they go by quickly.  The game tries really hard to be funny but there's not much humor to be found when nothing makes any sense, barring a couple lines from side characters.From a technical standpoint, the game is a bit odd.  It has very simple graphics and should run on a toaster due to that but for some reason is limited to 60 fps.  Keyboard movement keys are not set by default so you have to do it yourself and the mouse control is very sluggish and stuttery.  The game also stutters occasionally.  All of these things are extremely strange for a game running on the Unity engine but it doesn't get in the way too much.So to summarize Jazzpunk is a very weird game held up entirely by weird random references and humor, neither of which work.  How this game has gotten over 90% positive reviews completely baffles me.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												Jazzpunk is a difficult game to review, but I'll give it my best shot.Wow would be a simple word to describe this game. If there is such a thing as a God, it is Jazzpunk. Jazzpunk is a very much experimental game, infusing just about everything under the sun with puns. Alot of puns. Jazzpunk also incorporates just about any game you can think of into one neat little package. Pizza version of Nazi Zombies. Here. Quake game based around weddings. Here.The story line, while short, is funny and compelling at the same time. The story focuses on espionage, set in a bright world that enfuses new technology with a background of bright, and colourful Art Deco motifs. There is a ton of exploring to do, easter eggs to find, and whole new games to play! If you follow the main story path, you're looking at 2, maybe 3 hours of gameplay. But combined with all the secrets, achivements and down right silly side-quests, you could easily extend your playtime to 4-5 hours or even more!I expected a more Thirty Flights of Loving feel to Jazzpunk, but I was mistaken. Jazzpunk (it's just such a fun word to say) is it's own game, heck, it's own genre. It's much more "in your face" than Thirty Flights of Loving, but that isn't always a bad thing. Jazzpunk is just a silly, good time, but doesn't take it too far but actually making all these silly things funny. Granted, you'll need an acute sense of humor to enjoy this game. But I sure enjoyed the hell out of it, and I hope too again soon.+ The jokes are actually funny. No Duke Nukem Forver nonsense.+ The music, art, character and charm of the game are all fantastic.+ Incorporates lots of secrets, mini-games, this game has it all. Seriously.- Story is short- The ending is a bit abrupt/cheap- The very fact that it does end.9.5/10.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												What a game this was.First let me say that I have been playing a few comedy games as of late, so I potentially could be burned out on them as a genre.I hate this game, this game from start to finish was in a word horrible. In a few words a horribly optimized, exceedingly gimmicky, and just plain boring game. I'm not going to concern you with the plot. If you're interested in this game you know enough about the plot to get you started.  It uses the LOL so random ROFL gimmick to get a rise out of you, and then just stares at you when you don't laugh. Seeming to ask you "What about the gun that turns pedestrians into pigeons don't you find funny?" And that's the thing, at first it sounds very funny, but after the tenth similar joke it gets to be really old and very grating. And then it drags it out for four more levels, begging you to laugh while you just sit silently staring at your screen.Honestly if you really need to play a comedy game, I would recommend the Stanley Parable, or pretty much anything else. The only way that I would pick this game up was if it was free and had played everything in my backlog five times, and even then I would still hesitate.tl;dr Don't get this game

content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
												Jazzpunk is one of the many ridiculous titles published by Adult Swim in the last couple years, thankfully it is the good kind of ridiculous. It is just silly and smart enough to make it worth recommending. On the surface the plot of Jazzpunk seems insignificant but there is quite a bit that is left implied that encourages thought. I finished the game in about two hours, however that isn't exactly a problem: the game relies on its humor and I could see it getting stale if the game were a few more hours long. If I had trouble with anything during my time with Jazzpunk, it was the soundtrack. It is a fantastic soundtrack and works excellently with the game, however when exploring the levels sometimes the looped music would become grating. It doesn't offer much in replayability either but there is a lot of variety to the game, offering some neat minigames and secrets. If you are interested in some memorable comedy, Jazzpunk has you covered.I paid ~$0.33 for Jazzpunk as part of the Humble Weekly Bundle: Extra Life 2015 bundle.
