content:
Posted: May 15, 2014



YouTube™ Video: Jazzpunk ✭ 1 - Jazzy Funk 

			Views: 21		

			I don't want games that look ultra realistic, I want the drugs that make reality look like this. My playthrough of the adventure (/action?) game Jazzpunk on PC with live commentary		

Jazzpunk presents itself as a parody of spy movies, but quickly wears out its welcome with never ending references and sight gags, most completely unrelated to the task at hand, leaving you with a thin vein of a plot to serve as a vehicle from one joke to the next.That’s not to say all the humour is bad, but a lot is random for the sake of being random. There's no narrative hooks for many of the jokes, they just exist for the sole purpose of delivering a punchline; experience it and move on. Funnily enough, the better jokes are ones that are actually tied into the game plot, making the others feel tacked on and unnecessary filler.There reigns the problem with the game; if you don't make an active effort to seek these jokes out, you'll miss most the content of the game (possibly without even meaning to) and probably finish the game within an hour. Even looking for them I finished at just shy of three hours, with the ending just kind of happening rather than being built up to. £9.99 for a game that feels like it was a student's spare time project seems rather hefty to me. At that price point, I'd rather just go watch a terrible blockbuster comedy, I'd probably enjoy it just as much.The game gets split up into levels, which are small but distinct zones. Actually, scrap small, most are tiny. They look nice enough, but they're mainly just straight lines with a few offshoots if you want to go indulge in the humour, and there is no other reason to go explore. There's not much else to say about the game because, well, there's not much else to the game. There's a bunch of mini-games, though Wedding Qake repeats, which was a "ha ha, okay" the first time, a revisit of the joke was needless. You can swat flies in a vase shop, I avoided smashing the vases and killed the flies, the only effect was I now had a fly swatter, that had no influence outside that game room. I went back and smashed the vases, no effect. Sadly the gameplay part of the game seems like an inconvenience just getting in the way of the game telling its next joke.Also, there's a Rita Repulsa gag (see power rangers circa 20 years ago). In a game released in 2014... Who's this aimed at again?True, games like Wario Ware get by without much of a narrative, but it also just takes you immediately from one gag to the next, not leaving you to seek it out.I do really like the aesthetics, the graphics, character design, the audio; it is actually a pleasant game to play from that point of view. It’s a shame it gets bogged down with trying to cram in as much 'humour' as possible at the expense of a more fleshed out main story arc.This is the game equivalent of going to a forum for the sole purpose of looking at a random assortment of animated gifs; just a series of out-of-context punchlines.I guess you might counter all this by saying it sounds like I bought a joke book and expected a novel, I guess that may be true to a certain extent. But I feel a more apt comparison is meeting a new group of people and having them telling all their in jokes and expecting you to laugh along with them without engaging in any actual conversation.If you're just looking for humour, then honestly, Jazzpunk will deliver that, you may not like everything (I'll put myself in that camp), but the chances are you'll find something to laugh at. Just beware that most the gameplay is in service of jokes... and going and looking for more jokes... oh and there's a frogger inspired mini game.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												I'm a fan of comedy: on a stage, in film, on TV, in games, etc.  I also like many kinds of humor, but the jokes in this game could have only been of interest to a 10 year old version of myself.  Luckily I got this on sale, but even then, 2 hours of cringe-inducing attempts at humor really make this a "poopy-at-best" experience.  It's enough there is practically no content.  Or that the sounds and voice acting are terrible (made worse if you play with headphones).  Or that the only high points are the swing wing and the mini games.If you want a few chuckles but mostly want to groan, get this game.If you want an actual game with actual funny moments: wait for if No One Lives Forever comes to Steam/GOG.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Quirky and fun, albeit short, game that's good if your looking for an hour or two to kill with some laughs. There's tons of little side things to explore and the art is unique and interesting, and most of the time your exploration is rewarded by the well-written comedy strewn about the game. Not a lot of games entice me to poke around every corner and click on everything like this one did. If this is your kind of humor, you'll probably love it. If not, well then you'll probably hate it.Dunno if it's worth 15 dollars (the only reason I can think of why the price is so high is because the developers had to pay for A) Drugs that assisted with the creation of this game, or B) the Adult Swim logo.) but if you've got the extra cash and are prepared to throw it at your screen for a brief hour or two of complete and total confusion, then by all means try it out!tl;dr This game broke my brain, rawr stars out of blarg.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												Jazzpunk's sense of humor will make or break your experience since the gameplay itself isn't fun. Most of the jokes are reliant on you laughing at something just because it's weird or unexpected. Another reviewer described it as going for "OMGSORANDOMLOL" with every joke and interaction. I couldn't agree more. If this is your deal, you'll enjoy it much more than I did. I still appreciated the game's art style, general focus on silliness, and creativity but it quickly felt like I was being told the same joke for the 1 hour it took to finish this $15 game. Only buy it on sale if you really like this kind of humor. Steam needs a "maybe" recommend option.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												Weird, wacky and wonderful. I can't think of a better way to waste my afternoon with my pants on.This is a fine addition to Adult Swim's stable of games. The opening sequence is inspired and is a demonstration of what can be done with minimalist graphics. The game play is straight foward and somewhat linear. I will play through again to pick up those little bits here and there I missed the first time. The humour is spot on and you'll probably find yourself laughing out loud at some of the silliness. My only complaint is the abruptness with which the game ends. Hopefully there will be DLC to expand the missions and fun.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												A very packed indie game with tons of classy references. This game is like a love letter to videogames with an art style that is very minimalistic. The missions are interesting, the characters and dialogue are hilarious, the gameplay is absurd, but at least doesn't take itself too seriously. If you want a nice funny game to unwind with that doesn't pressure you into dying or timed sequences and will not frsutrate you in even the slightest, get this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												I will be honest, I haven't even finished this game yet and I feel that I have already got my money's worth from this. It's an extremely unique comedy experience that delivers on its promise of fun. Interact with as many things as you can and you will be rewarded in spades with smiles on your face.Let me put it this way: there is an entity you may encounter who is a direct parody of Rita from Power Rangers, Chikita Banana, and Fruit Ninja. You also get to degauss pigeons in a level. There are even items that take you into mini games when you interact with them.The comedy is fast-paced and doesn't wave itself in your face in an annoying "DO YOU GET IT?" way. The joke comes and goes fast enough for if you actually don't get it you'll get to see something else and laugh at that instead. It's also worth reading signs too, even small ones and labels. Quite frankly, a game that includes "Deep Fried Katamari" as a menu item in a place and will allow you to miss it really "gets" this brand of comedy and won't drag you down.Also, there's no pressure to do anything in a timely manner. I like that in this type of game.I highly recommend it, particularyly to anyone who knows quite a bit about technology, are at least slightly familiar with the aesthetic of 1956-1960, and/or are a bit aware of Japanese culture. If you're not familiar with any of that, I'm sure you'll find the visual humor entertaining still.The only criticism I have is that occasionally you run into a thing or two that lacks polish, such as the odd audio file that cuts out prematurely, but with the large amount of voice acting it's really not a big deal and it's only been the tail end. It's certainly not brought me out of the fun I've been having!Bottom Line: if you love a bit of smart absurdity, this is definitely a game worth looking into. If you're worried about short gameplay, think about how much it costs to go to the movie theater for a couple hours (at the most) and how this game will provide much more.

Posted: February 8, 2014
												When I bought Jazzpunk I did not know what this game was about. After playing the game to completion I still don't. This is a game that even once it hints things are going to start to make sense, throws a curve ball of absurdity right at your face. The best way to describe this would be taking Bubsy 3D or Frog Fractions and mixing it with Thirty Flights of Loving or Gravity Bone. I enjoyed every minute of it, and I desperately want to jump back in and try to find the things I missed. Highly recommended if you are a fan of absurdist comedy and referencial humor.

												I'll start off by saying that this is a really short game. You can beat this game most likely under an hour. But, the overall visuals makes up for it. The atmosphere presented in this game very enticing. It almost makes you want to explore the environment rather than continuing forward with the objective. The story is very humorous along with the silly voice acting. With all these elements combined, it makes a great game worth playing. My one and only complaint is the duration of the game. Being short. Despite that fact. If you're looking to get a good laugh, or a short game, this is the one for you. I recommend!

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												90’s cartoons + film noir + 90’s video game references.          So there I was browsing the steam store at the beginning of the summer sale, hundreds of games on sale, with crazy deals, like 60-80% off some great games, from great game makers. Plenty of tried and true games for me to buy, from franchises that probably wouldn’t disappoint, but I was looking for something new, something interesting, something I hadn’t played before, and by golley did I find it. So just what is jazzpunk, you say? Well the short answer would be that it’s a walking sim, but the long answer would be a trippy, windy road, full of some of the most distinct hummer I’ve ever seen in a game.           The game opens up by dumping you off of a luggage conveyer belt, into a sweeping montage of abstract imagery, full of Japanese symbols, air planes, and radio waves. It looks like something that could have been taken from the intro of an old western movie, if the motif were jazz, and not the Wild West. When it’s over, you get tossed in something that looks like a 50’ds-60’ds office space, crossed with a train station, and yes you can immediately start talking to boxes that are lying around.         A couple of minutes later and boom you’re in the full swing of the games plot, working as a secret agent  for the “Director”, and his “Secretary”. Right when you sit down on the whoopee cushion, to talk to your new boss, little white cartoonish lines come out of his eyes directing you towards you’re first mission objective, which is to raid some kind of Russian compound. Rite from the get go, you can get a good idea of what this games all about. Then you take you’re happy pills and go off into crazy land. This kind cartoonish hummer is bursting forth from almost every inch of the game. And that’s defiantly its strongest point, unlike most other walking sims this game won’t ever leave you board, whether you’re talking to insane hobos, hipster pies, that where sunglasses, and smok cigarettes, or talking to sexy female robots, there is always some business to poke your nose into. The game is also full of crazy side quests that you can get from talking to said persons such as; destroying clay pots in a fly shop, helping a frog cross the freeway to get his startreck data visor, catching huge spiders in a glass jar, in some Japanese themed restaurant, just to throw them on the cook’s face, who hates spiders.        This game is full of WTF moments that will have you smiling, and laughing out loud, as it pulls out gage after gage, most of which can be traced back to classic Ren and Stimpy cartoon's, and video game hummer. I even remember thinking halfway through the game “Ok, when are they going to start playing The Thieving Magpie theme?” and sure enough, there it was in the final level. But it’s really more than a one trick pony as far as the type of gages the game pulls off. Some of them are dialog based, some teleport you into areas where you are fighting cars, street fighter style in first person, and others are things like pulling an ice alarm, that’s located right next the proper fire alarm. Ice alarm, “for what reason”, one might ask one’s self? Why, for the same reason the hallway right next to it has a caution "greased up floor" sign on it. “Well that doesn’t make any sense.” you might say, however to that I would say, “Nothing in this game makes sense.”, but it's still a blast.       If you’re into shooting pigeon’s with crazy magnet guns taking their guts, and spraying "essence of pigeon" on other people, while other pigeons flock to them, to carry them off into the sky, then you will probably have fun with this game. Perhaps I write this review in vain, as it’s difficult to put into words what this game exactly is, but it’s defiantly worth playing. The only complaint I have is that it’s pretty short, if it had 2-3 more missions it would have been perfect. 9/10

content:
Posted: February 6, 2014



YouTube™ Video: Let's Play JAZZPUNK - Part 1 - Downright Hilarious! 

			Views: 23,993		

			This is a jazz & punk part of my blind Jazzpunk let's play (not walkthrough). The game is available on the PC via Steam or the official Jazz Punk game website. A first person hilarious adventure.		

Jazzpunk for me is like the drug you're looking for after coming home from work. It relaxes you, makes your jaw hurt from so much laughing at hilarious, sometimes idiot moments.There's a lot of easter eggs, references to gaming, movies, politics, anything you can imagine. There should definitely be more seasons/episodes for Jazzpunk.Recommended if you don't mind being placed in awkward situations.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8
												What a huge disappointment.  It gives off a presentation of being crazy and wacky, with old-school roots in its humor - poking fun with the 1960's version of sci-fi tech and trying to throw you off with wild scenarios and pop-art.  What it actually comes across as is nonsensical bull♥♥♥♥♥♥with boring pop culture references.Minor spoilers I guess.  I got to punch a car, and we both had yellow life bars, and when I destroyed it it said "You Win!  Perfect!".  I found a "public domain man in carbonite".  There was a James Bond intro sequence, what with him shooting the camera.  I clicked a thing and an orcish hand appeared, with a "Something need doing?" voice line being played among other things.  I had a resort receptionist recite the Konami code to me as something to try to fix my complaints.  I once played as a cat to tear around an apartment tearing things up because cats are evil xDDD.  There's more than one Wilhelm scream.  Leetspeak, conspiracy theorists, and a voice acted line saying something to the likes of "this is just background noise, the player won't even notice" all line up to pinpoint very naive humor with weak delivery.  It's not creatively introduced into the game, it just exists because pop culture.  Each new encounter with such things just made me sigh and consider stopping playing.In the first level, there's a ton of things to interact with, except you have to go out of your way to poke them, and the result is just garbage.  Sometimes literally.  Characters and objects spout unfunny gibberish in no relation to the universe or game.  After doing "side quests" and poking around the whole level, I was so bored I actively avoided almost everything extra in the rest of the game.  I could slam even more content, but instead I'll try not to drool all over myself.There's something promising underneath all of this, but I'm having a hard time figuring out what.  The few minutes in my under-two-hour completion time where I was doing actual "60's spy things" and not being bombarded by bird crap - again, sometimes literally - gave me a small hope it would expand into something more interesting.  Nope.  Just a series of art projects linked by 5 second music loops.Edit:  Wanted to add that the art and aesthetics in the game are unique and inviting in and of themselves, and I do appreciate a good chunk of them, as much of it is well-presented.  Heck, the intro sequence could be a standalone animation.  Unfortunately I don't find that enough to carry the rest of the game's weight.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2014



YouTube™ Video: Jazzpunk Review 

			Views: 785		

			Let's take a look at the upcoming Steam game Jazzpunk in this first impressions review, with a little bit of an informal twist! Here's a gameplay video of the first 20 minutes!		

You've never really played a game like Jazzpunk before. It shares  things in common with recent "walking simulators" Gone Home & The Stanley Parable. In Jazzpunk the goal is to procrastinate, and do anything but the level's objective.  You want to explore every corner of every map, and the goal is to experience the hilarious jokes that this game has to offer. The jokes range from incredible video game references all the way to adult humour. Unfortunately, the game last about 3 hours, and thre's an abrupt ending. However, the game is beyond hilarious and probably worth your time.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												Jazzpunk is a wonderful game that really is horribly short. The beginning is a great introduction to a world that is reminicent of a 60's spy flick mixed with 80's cyberpunk. Off-beat comedy is everywhere, and it benefits from adventure-style gameplay. There are no complex puzzles, but you will need to experiment and click on things to advance. You will likely not be challenged, and unfortunitely, there isn't much reason for a second playthrough. I got everything I wanted from one go through, messing with everything I could find.Oddly, the biggest failing of this game is it's exploration, in that there simply isn't enough. One entire level is merely a night version of an earlier one, and it possesses the same jokes and side events as the day version. Also, there where at least two occasions when I wished there was an alternative action or possibility than the ones you are forced into in order to proceed with the story. A cliched lapse in judgement brings about a briefly, inarguably unfunny event that amounted to the plot getting in the way of the fun. The final portion of the game recovers, but the ending failed to impress me. I don't regret buying it, but Jazzpunk is not worth full price.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												Let me tell you something about Jazzpunk, it is too often the problem with adventure games that the logic behind the puzzles is completely random nonsense, forcing you to hunt and peck everything against everything to succeed. Not so here! The nonsense behind the puzzles are completely consistent, and the designers did quite a good job of putting you into the headspace to solve their particular brand of Illogical challenges. Combine that with Some clever humor and terrific visuals and you have the makings of a masterpiece. My only fears for this game is that it will either sell Poorly preventing Stuff like it from being made in the future, or have negative reviews From casual gamers who just aren't quite ready for this outstanding experience.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
												Jazzpunk is a game that you won't know if you like it unless you experience it for yourself. As much as I enjoy these walking simulator games like The Vanishing of Ethan Carter and The Stanley Parable, Jazzpunk does not meet the quality you expect from these games by its narrative, immersion nor in its writing (especially its humor). Warning: Epilepsy Gamers, Beware.I wouldn't recommend this game as the intro screen and various moments in the game have tons of flashing lights.Chalk Full of Gags, Little ElseComedy is not something I'm going to critique the game for. It's too subjective, but I think I know who it's audience. This game comes across as another Youtube Bait game (Goat Simulator, etc.). The humor only seems to work off of "LOL RANDOM NONSENSE, WHAT DO YOU THINK?", which makes the game itself feel shallow to play alone. The game is chalk full of random mini-games, techy/nerdy/video-game references, and tons of open environments with various gags to be found. If you explore everything and exhaust all the dialogue, you'll probably get five decent hours of a playthrough. But with so many unnecessary nonsense gags, you might grow tired from the game's charm after the first area. And don't expect getting a narrative worth those five hours (at best). If You Still Want It, Buy It On A SaleThere's nothing for me to analyze in its mechanics nor anything story-wise to keep me interested in reviewing Jazzpunk. I liked the aesthetic, the soundtrack and the spy-hero gags/moments of the game. I wanted more of the riddiculous espionage humor, but that gets burried amongst the LOL moments that I quickly grew bored of. Some people may enjoy the more obscure references and the novelty of Jazzpunk. I sure don't see the appeal of a game of easter eggs. What's the surprise if you know that is the gag?

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												I found this game to be incredibly boring.  It tried way too hard to be funny but the lack of quality and variety in the art and voice acting just didn't do it for me.Tone down the polygon count and some textures and this is something you could find on N64, yet the performance was still abysmal.  It seems as though there's a memory leak or something because sometimes performance gets progressively worse after certain events.  A 6-core CPU with a R9 290 should be able to handle this game.I have often found myself struggling to point polyblank in a specific direction (when using a mouse+keyboard) where my view would sometimes change by 30 degrees when the mouse pointer may have only moved by 1 pixel.  Incredibly annoying.  I often found myself walking backwards towards a doorway since it was the only way I could control the direction I was moving in.The music in the game was crap, most "songs" only lasted maybe 20 seconds at most, and they were all on loop.  They also sounded like they had a 64Kbps compression.  On top of that, the volume of many sound effects are way too loud.You can't lose at the game and it gives absolutely no incentive to try anything.  I could complete an achievement and the game never acknowledges it.  The game is hardly a good time waster.I have played free games made by amateurs that were more fun and higher quality than this.  Even without the technical issues, this would be the worst game I own on Steam by far.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												Where do I begin...        Set during what I suppose is the Cold War, in what I THOUGHT was Japan, this is one trippy journey into a sweet♥♥♥♥♥world. I've always had a thing for the Eisenhower/JFK era: late 50s early 60s. I also had the pleasure to live in Japan, but my Pops, he had the pleasure to live in Japan during the Cold War. I play games not to get away, but to explore worlds I could never go in real life. This is the closest to 1960s Japan I'll probably ever get.        Jazzpunk is a first person exploration game. There's no real firm location except for one chapter.  The story is not very cut and dry. You play the role of a freelance "Spy" operative. It's never really stated who you ultimately work for, but know The Director is your boss. Really, the story is not it's strength. It's more of a visual adventure into someone's trippy mind. You interact with the world and watch the results. Gags, and jokes galore. Oh the gags! It's hard to categorize the game, the fun is in your curiosity. Walk around each location, and EXPLORE. It's a visual piece of art in my opinion, and the art design is superb. A "retro-futuristic" (think The Jetsons) Japanese aesthetic all thrown into a blender and somehow not coming out as sloppy as you would think. The music has it's strength. It works VERY well with the world. I can't even categorize the music...Latin, Bassnova, Jazz, 1950s shopping music???        The few cons I have is the price tag. Its a very short game, and the content may not justify the price for some. I also noticed other reviewers reporting motion sickness. For me, this was true. The camera is very sensitive to controls and I found myself getting sick. POV movement is quick and fast. Changing sensitivity might help.         This is one my favorite games ever, and I wish there was more to it. I never thought I'd see the day Quake, Street Fighter; It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World and Johnny "Cache" all get referenced in one piece of artwork! Luis Hernandez is definitley on another world. Glad he chose to share it with us. If you have an open mind, if you have an interest in the culture of the 50s and 60s; or if you just want to try something different, this game is for you. One last thing: did Japan win the war in this universe?Thanks for the trip Mr. Hernandez. I'll raise my bottle of Sake to you.

Posted: January 22
												I'm conflicted about this game.It's very silly, and has plenty of fun points, but the game lacks cohesion. While it's fun to run around and try to find each hidden joke or intractable set piece, you quickly learn that most of the things you interact with have no effect on the overall story, and are little more than a distraction. If a player chooses to ignore all the random set pieces of simply focuses on the main objectives the game can be finished in under and hour.Honestly if you're looking for a funny, joke-filled game, you'd be better off playing something like Phychonauts.

Posted: July 4, 2015
												Jazzpunk feels like a labour of love, a finely crafted adventure game crammed to the rim with zany, madcap humour; pop-culture references to please even the most devout hipsters; and wonderful little easter eggs. You can really tell the developers had a lot of fun making this game, but not as much as you will playing through it.The only concern you should have with this title is its steep price, especially as you can finish the game in two hours, but this is definitely a must purchase when it goes on sale.Remember; it's a fun thing, it's a Swing Wing!

content:
Posted: November 4, 2016
												This is a walking simulator with light puzzle elements and plenty of 4th wall breaking. Probably entertaining to those who are bored with games with stories, gameplay, or personality beyond references to things they might remember if they are around 30 years old or so, or might have heard their parents talk about. This is the kind of game that will either please you if you aren't into playing games for their systems and mechanics, or repel you: make you play it for an hour or so hoping something beyond simple visual gags, random dialog, and done-to-death 3D tricks you should have seen a dozen or so times by now will happen, until you realize that's all this game has to offer.TLDR this is a game for walking sim fans or people with nostalgia glasses coated so thick with old references and humor they can't even see their noses.The first mission is the best part of the game.

Posted: June 22, 2014
												Hilarious and deeply strange adventure game. It's a blast to go through the story here, but it's just as fun to explore each area, because there's a lot to see and hear and do. This game absolutely rewards your ability to not simply pursue a given end goal with tons of tomfoolery--and a handful of excellent minigames. This is also the first game in ages where I really wanted to unlock all the achievements; it was fun to do so.The imagery is colorful, cool and not quite like any other game I've ever seen, and the music and sound frequently enhance visual gags. There's excellent punning throughout, too--the writing and voice acting are probably cause for the funniest parts of the game. Charm and wit and humor all over.I absolutely recommend this game if you're willing to goof off with it. It was a really satisfying experience for me as a result.

Posted: March 29, 2014
												I thoroughly enjoyed this game. I can't say much about it without spoiling the experience, and the experience is pretty much the whole game, but I can give you some advice:This game is not for everyone. that said, if you want to give it a try, you have to be in the right mindset. This is not a traditional game, in any sense of the word. For one, none of the challenge comes from skill. Some people might say that makes it not challenging at all. I happen to disagree. The challenge, and indeed the enjoyment, come from searching the environment and seeing what wacky things you can find.Shoot, this is hard. I can't give any examples without spoiling a signifncant part of the (Exceedingly short) game.Look, the game is cheap, just try it. If it's the game for you you'll know it. Just don't go into it expecting anything in particular and you'll enjoy it that much more.

Posted: November 21, 2015
												Jazzpunk is a wierd little gem set in the era of Cold War secrecy and espionage. You play an agent (so far, at least) who must gather intelligence. You do this through various drug trips, which are entered after consuming some pills from your handler. This game is absolutely bizarre. There are thousands (literally) of small little events that can be triggered which end in all sorts of weird ways. For instance, if you pop some guys bubble (from his gum), it will pop on his face, blinding him and causing him to run into traffic. Is it relevant to the story? Absolutely not. Is it funny regardless? Sure is!The art style, chilling soundtrack, and arching story of the game keep me coming back time and time again. I highly recommend this extremely weird title.

Posted: November 10, 2015
												15 Dollar pricetag for a game made with few original assets. TL;dr not worth the cost. Get it if it goes on sale for 50 cents. Nothing more.Gameplay looks as if it's trying to mimic something from Blendo Games, and fails short. I may have given a bad review to 30 Flights, but at least that title lacked the design flaws that occasionally stand out later in the game. Then there is the matter of asset flipping. Using assets made by someone else and then dropping them almost tetris-like into unity to make a quick buck. This does no good for the consumer. Even Jim Sterling thinks so, at least I thought he did until I saw his name in the credits as a voice actor. Then there is the matter of some of the "plot puzzles" being nothing more than references for aging gen-x'ers, aka old people. The Captain Crunch blue whistle for the 2600hz control tone for the phone line is one example of many. Can I say this game is worth buying? It's not even worth owning. The quality of this game falls into that category of indie freebie that you download once, play for a while then delete and never play again because it wasn't a memorable enough experience. If it goes on sale for $0.50 USD or less get it. For half of a dollar maybe, anything more is not worth it.

Posted: March 18, 2014
												How do I best describe this game? Hilarious. Nonsensical. Downright disgusting at points, but awesome. Amazing. Very few words can describe such a fun little indie game full of jazz, computers, minigames and PIGEONS! As Polyblank, a robot in the future where the world was taken over by 'em, you are sent on missions from the Director as you meet foes and allies alike. However, at a resort getaway meant as a vacation from the tiring work, the evil Editor kidnaps you and brings you to his room in the resort (pretty strong bromance there, guys). You escape and find your way out, only to be sent back to a fake beginning! Doesn't make sense? It shouldn't, so don't worry.All-in-all, Jazzpunk is a must have for your Steam library, and nothing should ever change that.

Posted: March 1, 2014
												If you like quirky, unorthodox games like The Stanley Parable, you will certainly get some enjoyment from it. Similarly to The Stanley Parable, it's a game that's less about winning and more about wandering about and seeing what you can do. There are a couple of big differences though.The first is that it's linear. There's only one path to take, and no amount of meandering through doors will change that. Instead, however, you are given large, open areas to explore, with a nice handful of jokes, minigames, and even the odd sidequest. If you try rushing through the objectives and getting to the end, you will miss out on most of the meat the game has to offer.The other difference is, obviously, the style. This is much more cartoony, with a nice dose of slapstick thrown in there. The humour is certainly a lot more visual than lyrical, although there's some good dialogue in there too.I would highly recommend this game if you're looking for something funny and quirky, a nice experience albeit short. On the other hand if you're looking for a traditional espionage game with stealth and whatnot, yeah this really isn't for you. Hitman this ain't. :P

Posted: February 15, 2014
Jazzpunk is one of the funniest games I've played in a long time. Its humor is irreverant, often bizarre, and is reminiscent of films like Airplane! or Blazing Saddles. Much of it is random, but in a an unexpected "why the hell is this happenening," way rather than the tired "throw in anything and hope its funny" way. Checking out a pile of rubbish has the game throwing confetti at you and congratulating you for checking said rubbish, taking a random bottle of pills could turn you into a horse, or inspecting a wedding cake could treat you to a short game of Wedding Quake.The premise is simple: you're a freelance spy sent to recover sensitive material. Each of the game's four main missions brings you to a new area populated with strange characters that all have unique, funny dialogue.The game is short; clocking in at just over 3 hours for me. It's even shorter if one ignores the side-stuff and just does the main missions, but that would be missing the point of the game. At its core, Jazzpunk is about exploration and finding just what weirdness lurks in the nooks and crannies of the game. Personally, I don't see much difference between spending $15 to see a comedy in a theatre or spending the same amount for a comedic game of a similar length. Regardless, even if you have to wait for a sale, Jazzpunk's oddball humor is not to be missed.

Posted: February 8, 2014
												Here is some gameplay footage;


YouTube™ Video:  

			Views: 0		



A lot of people critisize short games for being, well, short. That's like saying the Falklands War never accounted for anything, because it really did. And this game does too.For it's decent off-sale price of £11.99 (or the equivalent) you get a game that explores many forms of game mechanics and comedy. In the game you catch pigeons, play a replica frogger game, play crazy golf with a pool cube, explore the digestive tracts of a crocodile, have an online match with other players over who marries who, cook a pig, fly about in a car, have a streetfighter-style match with a car, play tennis with a replica virtual boy and race gravy pots around a penthouse water feature filled with instant gravy granuales. And that's only just skimming the the top of the custard-covered apple crumble.Despite it only being around an hour and a half long, it has a large replay value. It's like when you watch a film for a second time; you see things that you didn't see before. There are numerous side quests, gags, easter eggs and weird happenings to find in the game all of which are too complicated to explain.If I was asked to explain the storyline to you, I can't. There's some mentionings of soviet embassies and editors, but it's really a big pile of slapstick comedy merged into a blob called Jazzpunk. Go buy this now. You will not regret it.

Posted: July 20, 2014
												When PC gaming first began, the genre at its head was the point and click adventure game. For years, games like King's Quest, Gabriel Knight, and The Curse of Monkey Island dominated the market. There were so many point and click games, every single idea one could have became used and abused, and the genre faded into one of gaming years past.JazzPunk is not your typical point and click adventure game.Firstly, it employs a clever mix of the classic Commodore 64 games and more modern shooters, giving you a game that feels like a shooter and plays like a classic. In addition, it has an abundance of something that just wasn't present in early games in the genre, and that's personality. The game will leave you holding your sides in its hilarious nonsense time and time again. Throw in a clever and unique art direction along side a perfect soundtrack, and you've got yourself the masterpiece that is JazzPunk.Despite this praise, Jazzpunk is not without fault. The biggest one is this: Its combination of floaty controls, psychedelic graphics, and low FoV will leave many users nauseous after just a few minutes of play. It can be a risky endeavor, play this game at your own risk. Another issue is that this game is quite short. for $15, you can find yourself beating this game in less than an hour. This may seem to be a ridiculous complaint to fans of The Stanley Parable, who know that for the same price you can finish the game in 20 minutes, but the fun in The Stanley Parable comes from its replay value. This game is all about exploration, but one can end their experience in a short amount of time, and there aren't 17 more endings to choose from. If one were to plan on buying this game, they need to be patient and search for secrets, otherwise they could be looking at a 45 minute game rather than a 4 hour one.All in all, JazzPunk is a creative and interesting experience. It blends unique game design with witty and pleasurable humor, but can be dangerous to users who are prone to epilepsy or motion sickness, as well as being a tad on the short side.

Posted: October 13, 2015
												Much like many others, this is hard to recommend. The game is a surreal 'comedy' in which you play the part of a secret agent tasked with a number of tasks all set in a very stylised world. The tasks are pretty easy to work out with some lateral thought, ie if it seems a bit silly more than likely your on the right track and there are some fun side quests to flesh things out. The story is pretty much second fiddle to the jokes. The issue is, its short. Very short. I finished it in 2 hours and i didnt feel compelled to go back and do the side quests i skipped. The humour, while funny enough to make a playthrough worthwhile sometimes falls a bit flat. Playing this put me in mind of the Accomplice series of books by Steve Aylett. i found myself compelled to continue, sometimes laughing but other times just wondering what i was reading. The game is nowhere near as dark but it felt similar in that i would find it hard to explain, just play it / read it, you will see.For the price though, no. Just no. £10.99 for approx 2 hours play time is just too much. Sale only. Pros:Its funny with a very unique art style Its more of an experience than a game and for that i applaud the devs for thinking out the boxIts good fun for the couple of hours playthough it providesCons:It will take you 2 hours :P.The humour could put some people off, lets face it, not everyone has the same sense of humour.Ill say recommended but only if you like the idea of playing though a surreal trip with no real challenge, its just something you hop onto to ride along and enjoy the rather silly show. Plus, i MUST be on sale, at least 50% off to even begin to justify the playtime.

Posted: February 12, 2014
												The spiritual successor to Lego Island and an incredible tribute to the classic spoof movies of the 80s (Airplane!, The Naked Gun). The game is a rollercoaster of ridiculous gags and an oddball setting that is three long, twisted steps away from James Bond gadgetry and cyberpunk. The game is never challenging and can be rushed through quickly (but what the ♥♥♥♥ is the point of that); the levels can be thought of as environments to explore and interact with to find secrets (a la Gone Home or The Stanley Parable). The scope of these secrets is immense, ranging from short slapstick gags to entire games-within-games that have to be seen to be believed. If you're not the kind of nerd who gets pissy about short games, Jazzpunk is absolutely worth your time and is one of the great examples of the finally-growing comedic game genre.

Posted: February 11, 2014
												According to indie developer Necrophone Games, Jazzpunk is a “comedy adventure game set in an alternate-reality cold war world, plagued with corporate espionage, cyber-crime and sentient martinis,” fused with gameplay supposedly inspired by spoof classics such as Airplane and Naked Gun. So, with a description as above, it is fair to suggest that I had no idea what to expect when I ‘cyberjacked into the netrix’ for the first time.Published by Adult Swim Games, whose notable successes include the absurd, quasi-addictive Robot Unicorn flash-game, it was always a reasonable guess that this title would be somewhat lacking in real-world sensibilities. By the time your character has consumed his prescription ‘Missionoyl’ medication (Guidelines for usage: take one capsule per mission until reality is sufficiently augmented), your assumptions are confirmed. Jazzpunk is Christian Bale crazy.You see the world through the eyes of Polyblank, an espionage agent of sorts, who, under the instruction of a peculiar gentleman known only as The Director, must infiltrate the Soviet consulate to obtain a top-secret data cartridge.Except, when you arrive at the location of your first mission, it doesn’t take too long to realise that the ‘storyline’ itself is as tenuous and stringy as overcooked spaghetti, it is purely the vehicle that transports the player from one fast-paced escapade to the next. This is not to say that there isn’t a vague storyline in place, but, to be playing this game for its storytelling narrative and character depth would be to miss the point entirely. Jazzpunk is intended to be a light-hearted poke at, well, pretty much everything.It is an ambitious notion, particularly for an indie games development team consisting of just two people. The good news, however, is that Luiz Hernandez and Jess Browse have succeeded in their primary aim, to make people laugh. After a promising but sluggish opening chapter, Jazzpunk really begins to gather pace, providing several genuine laugh-out-loud moments, generally involving pigeons.However, Jazzpunk isn’t just the quirky chick that nobody wants to take to the prom. She’s pretty, too. A vivid cartoon landscape adorns the open-world environment, and Hernandez himself has composed an original soundtrack, which wouldn’t sound out of place in a 1950’s motion picture.Help From a Few FriendsThose hoping for a little more than an interactive comedy can also rest assured, Jazzpunk is not short of good old fashioned gameplay. Mini-game appearances from favourites such as Frogger, Fruit Ninja and Space Invaders creep up on you when you least expect it, as well as an incredible wedding-themed parody of Quake, in which players must use champagne corks as projectiles in order to avoid the prospect of matrimonial doom.The game builds to a resoundingly triumphant climax. An Olympic style multi-format duel with the story’s main antagonist, The Editor (or ‘The Man with the Horn Rimmed Glasses,’ as he is originally introduced), continues to raise the ridiculousness stakes, and an epic gravy boat race (yes, that’s what I said) closes the battle magnificently.Jazzpunk, a nominee for the grand prize at this year’s Independent Games Festival, is a thoroughly enjoyable experience from start to finish. It shares some similarities with fellow IGF nominee The Stanley Parable in its ability to not just break, but smash the fourth wall, yet still remain exciting. However, where it stands apart from TSP, and the vast majority of other computer games to date, is its steadfast commitment to being absolutely mental.Too Much of a Good Thing?Of course, the off-the-wall nature of this title will mean that it will not be for everyone. If you are expecting an experience that follows traditional gameplay protocol then you will be confused, let down, and most likely irritated. Jazzpunk is wacky, in a way that is simply incomparable to anything else I have ever seen. It is an explosive compound of equal parts satire and slapstick, noir and nerd, sublime and ridiculous.On the whole, Jazzpunk seems to completely merit its reception as one of the best independent games to be released this year. In terms of replay-ability, it is very solid. Having completed the full-story twice, I was able to find plenty of content that I had missed on my opening play-through, which kept it fresh and engaging.The humour is likely to be hit-and-miss, based on personal preference. But, for this soul, Jazzpunk is an extremely funny and refreshing piece of work.http://www.pixeldynamo.com/reviews/2014/02/06/3554/jazzpunk-pc-review/

Coming in at around two hours long, Jazzpunk is a game that is worth the plunge for the adventurous gamer.

Posted: June 3, 2015
JazzpunkThis is a pretty strange game to be honest, though in a good way, at least in my opinion. Although the cartoonish graphics are nice, and the storyline is okay, I think that the bad jokes and puns, combined with the side-quests and minigames scattered around really make this game.It's just so fun to explore and do things completely random and different; things you've never done before, like capturing birds so someone can bake a pie with them, or 'swatting' flies in a vase shop (you can imagine how that turned out).Jazzpunk is like nothing I have ever played before, and I highly recommend it.Although there have been a few issues with this game e.g. me being confused and using up an item that i was supposed to use to progress in the game (SPOILER-with the gravy granules within the Bachelor Pad Chapter I didn't read the text on the table, and didn't throw the granules in the water, instead I just used them all, and then had to re-play an area to get back).To conclude, I have greatly enjoyed my few hours of playtime so far. I may even replay this game at some point in the future, to try and find anything that I may have missed the first time while playing.10/10 - Odd, but a very unique game. And funny at times, too! :D

												Jazzpunk is a funny, engaging little game that suffers from a short story but is bolstered exceptionally by amusing dialogue,  achievements that actually make you think about them (mostly) and entertaining tidbits hidden throughout the landscape that seem to add an overall "panache" to the game itself. Posted: December 22, 2014
												Jazzpunk is a First-person game, but it's not a shooter. It's more of a FPC, First-Person Comedy. It's really funny, and it turns a lot of the FPS genre tropes on their head. It is a parody of, not only the genre, but also a big chunk of the medium as a whole and of pop culture from the 90's to today. It covers a lot of ground in very little time. You'll see everything in less than 5 hours, but that's one of the things that makes it good in my opinion. It doesn't overstay it's welcome.It's full of nonsensical visual gags, cheap and fast puns, and wacky physical humor. Normally, all of this would equate to something that is difficult to spend very much time with, but Jazzpunk's atmosphere remains inviting throughout. A lot of the jokes may be cheap, but they continue to get a big laugh from me until the very end.

Posted: September 10, 2015
												  This is a quirky and fun adventure-type game.  I say adventure-type because while you are trying to solve puzzles, they are, thus far in my admittedly short play-time, quite easy.  The pull of this game is the stylized 60's spy-thriller setting.  Basically you are given a set-piece environment that you explore and try to "solve" to make it to the next level.  There are opportunities to interact with a number of objects in the game, including "characters" that rather look like they belong on public washroom doors to identify "men's" and "women's", with some terrible-but-in-a-good-way puns and jokes.  One caution I would give is that this is a first person game.  Your character "runs" smoothly across the environment with no bobbing or jumping.  As the environments are very busy and colourful, I found myself feeling a little motion sickness at times.  Admittedly I am succeptable to this phenomenon, and by simply moving more slowly and in more straight lines I was able to continue.  I would also like to suggest there be an EPILEPSY warning for this game.  The intro scene in particular was intense with flashing lights and crazy sounds.  My 9 year old daughter saw this and immediately wanted to play it.  There are some risque jokes, but really it's pretty PG.  Additionally, many of the jokes went right over her head, particularly the non-sequiturs and those referencing old computer terminology.  She was mainly attracted to the blocky and colourful artwork and the physical jokes, of which there are plenty.  The music and sound are particularly mentionable.  The "Jazzpunk" music is a blend of jazz and... I'm not sure punk exactly.  Imagine Miles Davis improvising with modern jazz while tripping on acid.  It can get a little much - but then again I'm old so what do I know?  I was able to get this game on sale, and at under $5 I can whole-heartedly recommend it.  If you are sitting on the fence about this one, I'd probably wait until it went on sale.  If you want to experience something unusual and trippy, then go for it.

Posted: February 22, 2015
												What is Jazzpunk? I've played through the game to 100% now (or at least 100% achievements, I'm sure I've missed some stuff along the way) and I still have no clue. It's a point and click adventure game, I guess, and there's some exploration to be had, too, and a bit of questing, and random minigames, and just... a lot, a lot of weird but great humor. So many times the game just pulls something out of nowhere that's completely unexpected but not just "LOLSORANDOM". Not all the humor is great but so much of it is and there are so frequently jokes that it's hard not to find it amusing. The game is really on the short side, but it makes it a tight, focused, fast-paced package and really that's all I can ask for. I'm not sure it's worth the $15 price tag, but on sale, it's a great buy.

Posted: February 11, 2014
												According to indie developer Necrophone Games, Jazzpunk is a “comedy adventure game set in an alternate-reality cold war world, plagued with corporate espionage, cyber-crime and sentient martinis,” fused with gameplay supposedly inspired by spoof classics such as Airplane and Naked Gun. So, with a description as above, it is fair to suggest that I had no idea what to expect when I ‘cyberjacked into the netrix’ for the first time.Published by Adult Swim Games, whose notable successes include the absurd, quasi-addictive Robot Unicorn flash-game, it was always a reasonable guess that this title would be somewhat lacking in real-world sensibilities. By the time your character has consumed his prescription ‘Missionoyl’ medication (Guidelines for usage: take one capsule per mission until reality is sufficiently augmented), your assumptions are confirmed. Jazzpunk is Christian Bale crazy.You see the world through the eyes of Polyblank, an espionage agent of sorts, who, under the instruction of a peculiar gentleman known only as The Director, must infiltrate the Soviet consulate to obtain a top-secret data cartridge.Except, when you arrive at the location of your first mission, it doesn’t take too long to realise that the ‘storyline’ itself is as tenuous and stringy as overcooked spaghetti, it is purely the vehicle that transports the player from one fast-paced escapade to the next. This is not to say that there isn’t a vague storyline in place, but, to be playing this game for its storytelling narrative and character depth would be to miss the point entirely. Jazzpunk is intended to be a light-hearted poke at, well, pretty much everything.It is an ambitious notion, particularly for an indie games development team consisting of just two people. The good news, however, is that Luiz Hernandez and Jess Browse have succeeded in their primary aim, to make people laugh. After a promising but sluggish opening chapter, Jazzpunk really begins to gather pace, providing several genuine laugh-out-loud moments, generally involving pigeons.However, Jazzpunk isn’t just the quirky chick that nobody wants to take to the prom. She’s pretty, too. A vivid cartoon landscape adorns the open-world environment, and Hernandez himself has composed an original soundtrack, which wouldn’t sound out of place in a 1950’s motion picture.Help From a Few FriendsThose hoping for a little more than an interactive comedy can also rest assured, Jazzpunk is not short of good old fashioned gameplay. Mini-game appearances from favourites such as Frogger, Fruit Ninja and Space Invaders creep up on you when you least expect it, as well as an incredible wedding-themed parody of Quake, in which players must use champagne corks as projectiles in order to avoid the prospect of matrimonial doom.The game builds to a resoundingly triumphant climax. An Olympic style multi-format duel with the story’s main antagonist, The Editor (or ‘The Man with the Horn Rimmed Glasses,’ as he is originally introduced), continues to raise the ridiculousness stakes, and an epic gravy boat race (yes, that’s what I said) closes the battle magnificently.Jazzpunk, a nominee for the grand prize at this year’s Independent Games Festival, is a thoroughly enjoyable experience from start to finish. It shares some similarities with fellow IGF nominee The Stanley Parable in its ability to not just break, but smash the fourth wall, yet still remain exciting. However, where it stands apart from TSP, and the vast majority of other computer games to date, is its steadfast commitment to being absolutely mental.Too Much of a Good Thing?Of course, the off-the-wall nature of this title will mean that it will not be for everyone. If you are expecting an experience that follows traditional gameplay protocol then you will be confused, let down, and most likely irritated. Jazzpunk is wacky, in a way that is simply incomparable to anything else I have ever seen. It is an explosive compound of equal parts satire and slapstick, noir and nerd, sublime and ridiculous.On the whole, Jazzpunk seems to completely merit its reception as one of the best independent games to be released this year. In terms of replay-ability, it is very solid. Having completed the full-story twice, I was able to find plenty of content that I had missed on my opening play-through, which kept it fresh and engaging.The humour is likely to be hit-and-miss, based on personal preference. But, for this soul, Jazzpunk is an extremely funny and refreshing piece of work.http://www.pixeldynamo.com/reviews/2014/02/06/3554/jazzpunk-pc-review/

Posted: February 20, 2015
												A damn good game. Not long mind you but, it doesn't need to be. It's a full story with unique gameplay.The best way to explain Jazzpunk...Imagine If Philip K.♥♥♥♥♥♥ Ian Fleming, & Hunter S. Thompson collaborated in a drug induced stuper (so the norm) on a trippy, witty piece of Cold War era spy quasi-fiction...(also the norm).Sadly,♥♥♥♥♥♥thought Fleming and Thompson were CIA and FBI agents. So he hid the manuscript in a hollowed out electric sheep lawn ornament.Some years later Ted Turner purchased the lawn ornament at an estate sale and asked for it be dropped off at the Williams Street offices while he was in the process of moving from Georgia to the Western Frontier.Fast foward to 2013, Some smuck at Adult Swim tripped over the sheep's power cord in the storage closet...breaking it and revealing the novella.and the rest is history.TL:DR; One of the funniest games & well written games I've ever played.

Posted: December 20, 2014
												Bad jokes, leddit gaemer culture xDxD references and 90 minutes of gameplay, not much more to say about this one.Oh wait, yeah. It's got a pretty solid art direction, like, top notch stuff. Reminded me a lot of Psychonauts in that respect. Sound design is also very solid, although the voices acting is kinda meh at times (to be more specific it feels like the voice distortion is borne more out of necessity than deliberation). The writing is... completely f*cking absurd, but that's the whole point, isn't it? All in all it's a nice effort, but terribly overpriced and suffer from the plague of many indie games coming out these days: lots of good ideas, too little time and money to make them work. Feels more like a student project than a commercial game if you know what I'm saying (saying this as a game design student in college). I r8 it 5/10, worth buying if it's like 75% off or in a bundle (like I got it).P.S.: Zoe Quinn did some stuff on it, voices and testing I think, just a heads up if you're one of those gamer gater people. IDGAF.

Posted: June 3, 2015
JazzpunkThis is a pretty strange game to be honest, though in a good way, at least in my opinion. Although the cartoonish graphics are nice, and the storyline is okay, I think that the bad jokes and puns, combined with the side-quests and minigames scattered around really make this game.It's just so fun to explore and do things completely random and different; things you've never done before, like capturing birds so someone can bake a pie with them, or 'swatting' flies in a vase shop (you can imagine how that turned out).Jazzpunk is like nothing I have ever played before, and I highly recommend it.Although there have been a few issues with this game e.g. me being confused and using up an item that i was supposed to use to progress in the game (SPOILER-with the gravy granules within the Bachelor Pad Chapter I didn't read the text on the table, and didn't throw the granules in the water, instead I just used them all, and then had to re-play an area to get back).To conclude, I have greatly enjoyed my few hours of playtime so far. I may even replay this game at some point in the future, to try and find anything that I may have missed the first time while playing.10/10 - Odd, but a very unique game. And funny at times, too! :D
